{epayet, fred}@univ-reunion.fr

A Generalization of the Lifting Lemma for Logic Programming

Etienne Payet â€ƒâ€ƒ Fred Mesnard
Abstract

Since the seminal work of J. A. Robinson on resolution, many lifting lemmas for simplifying proofs of completeness of resolution have been proposed in the literature. In the logic programming framework, they may also help to detect some infinite derivations while proving goals under the SLD-resolution. In this paper, we first generalize a version of the lifting lemma, by extending the relation â€œis more general thanâ€ so that it takes into account only some arguments of the atoms. The other arguments, which we call neutral arguments, are disregarded. Then we propose two syntactic conditions of increasing power for identifying neutral arguments from mere inspection of the text of a logic program.

Contents

  1. 1.

    Introduction

  2. 2.

    Preliminaries

  3. 3.

    Neutral Arguments for SLD-Derivation

    1. 3.1

      Filters

    2. 3.2

      Derivation Neutral Filters: Operational Definition

    3. 3.3

      Model Theoretic Results Induced by DN Filters

  4. 4.

    Some Particular DN Filters

    1. 4.1

      DN Sets of Positions

    2. 4.2

      DN Sets of Positions with Associated Terms

  5. 5.

    Atomic Queries with Infinite Derivations

  6. 6.

    Related Works

  7. 7.

    Conclusion

  8. 8.

    Bibliography

  9. 9.

    Proofs

1 Introduction

Since the seminal work of J. A. Robinson on resolution [16], many lifting lemmas have been proposed in the literature, see for instance [5] p. 84, [2] p. 848, [11] p. 47, [1] p. 60 or [8] where a stronger version than that of [1] is given. Lifting results are used as a tool to simplify proofs of completeness of resolution.

In this paper, we are interested in generalizing the lifting lemma presented in [1] where it is called the Lifting Theorem. Given a logic program Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P, our aim is the further design of a mechanism that generates at compile-time classes of queries that have an infinite SLD-derivation w.r.t. Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P. Towards this end, we propose a criterion in the form of a sufficient condition that enables us to identify infinite derivations.

Notice that such a condition can be easily designed from the Lifting Theorem that is proposed by Apt in [1], as we explain now. Assuming that the reader is familiar with the standard notations about logic programming reviewed in the next section, let us first recall the notion of a lift. An SLD-derivation Î¾â€²superscriptğœ‰â€²\xi^{\prime}italic_Î¾ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a lift of another SLD-derivation Î¾ğœ‰\xiitalic_Î¾ if there exists a prefix Dğ·Ditalic_D of Î¾â€²superscriptğœ‰â€²\xi^{\prime}italic_Î¾ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT that is more general than Î¾ğœ‰\xiitalic_Î¾ i.e. Dğ·Ditalic_D is of the same length than Î¾ğœ‰\xiitalic_Î¾ and in Dğ·Ditalic_D and Î¾ğœ‰\xiitalic_Î¾ the same clauses are used in the same order, atoms in the same positions are selected at each step and for each iğ‘–iitalic_i, the iğ‘–iitalic_i-th query of Dğ·Ditalic_D is more general than that of Î¾ğœ‰\xiitalic_Î¾. The following result holds.

Theorem 1.1 (Lifting [1])

Let Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P be a logic program, Qğ‘„Qitalic_Q be a query and Î·ğœ‚\etaitalic_Î· be a substitution. For every SLD-derivation Î¾ğœ‰\xiitalic_Î¾ of Pâˆª{Qâ¢Î·}ğ‘ƒğ‘„ğœ‚P\cup\{Q\eta\}italic_P âˆª { italic_Q italic_Î· }, there exists an SLD-derivation of Pâˆª{Q}ğ‘ƒğ‘„P\cup\{Q\}italic_P âˆª { italic_Q } which is a lift of Î¾ğœ‰\xiitalic_Î¾.

This theorem provides a sufficient condition that can be used to identify infinite SLD-derivations.

Corollary 1

Let Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P be a logic program and Ağ´Aitalic_A be an atom. Suppose that there exists a sequence of SLD-derivation steps from Ağ´Aitalic_A to a query Qğ‘„Qitalic_Q using the clauses of Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P and that Qğ‘„Qitalic_Q contains an atom BğµBitalic_B that is more general than Ağ´Aitalic_A. Then there exists an infinite SLD-derivation of Pâˆª{A}ğ‘ƒğ´P\cup\{A\}italic_P âˆª { italic_A }.

Proof

Let Aâ¢âŸ¹P+Qğ´subscriptsuperscriptâŸ¹ğ‘ƒğ‘„A\mathop{\Longrightarrow}\limits^{+}_{P}Qitalic_A âŸ¹ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q denote that there exists a sequence of SLD-derivation steps from Ağ´Aitalic_A to Qğ‘„Qitalic_Q using the clauses of Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P. As BğµBitalic_B is more general than Ağ´Aitalic_A, by the Lifting TheoremÂ 1.1 we have Bâ¢âŸ¹P+Q1ğµsubscriptsuperscriptâŸ¹ğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘„1B\mathop{\Longrightarrow}\limits^{+}_{P}Q_{1}italic_B âŸ¹ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT where Q1subscriptğ‘„1Q_{1}italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a query that is more general than Qğ‘„Qitalic_Q. So there exists B1subscriptğµ1B_{1}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in Q1subscriptğ‘„1Q_{1}italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT that is more general than BğµBitalic_B. Iterating this process, we construct an infinite sequence of queries Q1subscriptğ‘„1Q_{1}italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, Q2subscriptğ‘„2Q_{2}italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, â€¦and an infinite sequence of atoms B1subscriptğµ1B_{1}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, B2subscriptğµ2B_{2}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, â€¦such that for iâ‰¥1ğ‘–1i\geq 1italic_i â‰¥ 1, Bisubscriptğµğ‘–B_{i}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is in Qisubscriptğ‘„ğ‘–Q_{i}italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Biâ¢âŸ¹P+Qi+1subscriptğµğ‘–subscriptsuperscriptâŸ¹ğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘„ğ‘–1B_{i}\mathop{\Longrightarrow}\limits^{+}_{P}Q_{i+1}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ¹ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. âˆ

Nevertheless, such a condition is rather weak because it fails at identifying some simple loops. This is illustrated by the following example.

Example 1

Let cğ‘citalic_c be the clause pâ¢(x,y)â†pâ¢(fâ¢(x),z)â†ğ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘ğ‘“ğ‘¥ğ‘§p(x,y)\leftarrow p(f(x),z)italic_p ( italic_x , italic_y ) â† italic_p ( italic_f ( italic_x ) , italic_z ). Then from the head of cğ‘citalic_c we get an SLD-derivation step pâ¢(x,y)â¢âŸ¹cpâ¢(fâ¢(x1),z1)ğ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘¦subscriptâŸ¹ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘“subscriptğ‘¥1subscriptğ‘§1p(x,y)\mathop{\Longrightarrow}\limits_{c}p(f(x_{1}),z_{1})italic_p ( italic_x , italic_y ) âŸ¹ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( italic_f ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). Since the atom pâ¢(fâ¢(x1),z1)ğ‘ğ‘“subscriptğ‘¥1subscriptğ‘§1p(f(x_{1}),z_{1})italic_p ( italic_f ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is not more general than pâ¢(x,y)ğ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘¦p(x,y)italic_p ( italic_x , italic_y ), CorollaryÂ 1 cannot be used. Moreover,

pâ¢(fâ¢(x1),z1)â¢âŸ¹cpâ¢(fâ¢(fâ¢(x2)),z2)â¢âŸ¹cpâ¢(fâ¢(fâ¢(fâ¢(x3))),z3)â¢â‹¯ğ‘ğ‘“subscriptğ‘¥1subscriptğ‘§1subscriptâŸ¹ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘“ğ‘“subscriptğ‘¥2subscriptğ‘§2subscriptâŸ¹ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘“ğ‘“ğ‘“subscriptğ‘¥3subscriptğ‘§3â‹¯p(f(x_{1}),z_{1})\mathop{\Longrightarrow}\limits_{c}p(f(f(x_{2})),z_{2})\mathop{\Longrightarrow}\limits_{c}p(f(f(f(x_{3}))),z_{3})\cdotsitalic_p ( italic_f ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) âŸ¹ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( italic_f ( italic_f ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) , italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) âŸ¹ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( italic_f ( italic_f ( italic_f ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) ) , italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) â‹¯

As the first argument of pğ‘pitalic_p grows from step to step, we will never be able to use CorollaryÂ 1 to show that there exists an infinite SLD-derivation of {c}âˆª{pâ¢(x,y)}ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘¦\{c\}\cup\{p(x,y)\}{ italic_c } âˆª { italic_p ( italic_x , italic_y ) }. âˆ

In this article, we extend the relation â€œis more general thanâ€ so that it takes into account only some arguments of the atoms, the others (which are called neutral arguments) being, roughly, disregarded. We show that the Lifting TheoremÂ 1.1, and hence CorollaryÂ 1, can be extended to this new relation. Neutral arguments correspond to the following intuition. Suppose we have an SLD-derivation Î¾ğœ‰\xiitalic_Î¾ of a query Qğ‘„Qitalic_Q w.r.t. a logic program Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P. Let Qâ€²superscriptğ‘„â€²Q^{\prime}italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be the query obtained by replacing the neutral arguments of the atoms of Qğ‘„Qitalic_Q by any term. Then, there exists an SLD-derivation Î¾â€²superscriptğœ‰â€²\xi^{\prime}italic_Î¾ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT of Qâ€²superscriptğ‘„â€²Q^{\prime}italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT w.r.t. Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P such that Î¾â€²superscriptğœ‰â€²\xi^{\prime}italic_Î¾ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a lift of Î¾ğœ‰\xiitalic_Î¾ up to the neutral arguments.

Example 2

Consider ExampleÂ 1 again. For any derivation step pâ¢(s1,s2)ğ‘subscriptğ‘ 1subscriptğ‘ 2p(s_{1},s_{2})italic_p ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) âŸ¹cpâ¢(s3,s4)subscriptâŸ¹ğ‘ğ‘subscriptğ‘ 3subscriptğ‘ 4\mathop{\Longrightarrow}\limits_{c}p(s_{3},s_{4})âŸ¹ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) if we replace s1subscriptğ‘ 1s_{1}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT by any term t1subscriptğ‘¡1t_{1}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT then there exists a derivation step pâ¢(t1,s2)â¢âŸ¹cpâ¢(t3,t4)ğ‘subscriptğ‘¡1subscriptğ‘ 2subscriptâŸ¹ğ‘ğ‘subscriptğ‘¡3subscriptğ‘¡4p(t_{1},s_{2})\mathop{\Longrightarrow}\limits_{c}p(t_{3},t_{4})italic_p ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) âŸ¹ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). Moreover, notice that s4subscriptğ‘ 4s_{4}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and t4subscriptğ‘¡4t_{4}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are variables, so pâ¢(t3,t4)ğ‘subscriptğ‘¡3subscriptğ‘¡4p(t_{3},t_{4})italic_p ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is more general than pâ¢(s3,s4)ğ‘subscriptğ‘ 3subscriptğ‘ 4p(s_{3},s_{4})italic_p ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) up to the first argument of pğ‘pitalic_p. Consequently, by the intuition described above, the first argument of pğ‘pitalic_p is neutral for derivation w.r.t. cğ‘citalic_c. Finally, as pâ¢(x,y)â¢âŸ¹cpâ¢(fâ¢(x1),z1)ğ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘¦subscriptâŸ¹ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘“subscriptğ‘¥1subscriptğ‘§1p(x,y)\mathop{\Longrightarrow}\limits_{c}p(f(x_{1}),z_{1})italic_p ( italic_x , italic_y ) âŸ¹ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( italic_f ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) and pâ¢(fâ¢(x1),z1)ğ‘ğ‘“subscriptğ‘¥1subscriptğ‘§1p(f(x_{1}),z_{1})italic_p ( italic_f ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is more general than pâ¢(x,y)ğ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘¦p(x,y)italic_p ( italic_x , italic_y ) up to the first argument which is neutral, by the extended version of CorollaryÂ 1 there exists an infinite SLD-derivation of the query pâ¢(x,y)ğ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘¦p(x,y)italic_p ( italic_x , italic_y ) w.r.t. cğ‘citalic_c. âˆ

Last but not least, we offer two syntactic conditions of increasing power for easily identifying neutral arguments from mere inspection of the text of a logic program.

The paper is organized as follows. In SectionÂ 2, we review basic concepts concerning logic programming and introduce some notations. Then in SectionÂ 3 we give a generic presentation of what we mean for an argument to be neutral. In SectionÂ 4, we propose some particular concrete means for detecting neutral arguments. In SectionÂ 5, we apply our results to generate some queries that have an infinite SLD-derivation w.r.t. a given logic program. Finally, in SectionÂ 6 we discuss related works.

2 Preliminaries

We try to strictly adhere to the notations, definitions, and results presented in [1].

Nğ‘Nitalic_N denotes the set of non-negative integers and for any nâˆˆNğ‘›ğ‘n\in Nitalic_n âˆˆ italic_N, [1,n]1ğ‘›[1,n][ 1 , italic_n ] denotes the set {1,â€¦,n}1â€¦ğ‘›\{1,\ldots,n\}{ 1 , â€¦ , italic_n }. If n=0ğ‘›0n=0italic_n = 0 then [1,n]=âˆ…1ğ‘›[1,n]=\varnothing[ 1 , italic_n ] = âˆ….

From now on, we fix a language â„’â„’\mathcal{L}caligraphic_L of programs. We assume that â„’â„’{\cal L}caligraphic_L contains an infinite number of constant symbols. The set of relation symbols of â„’â„’\cal Lcaligraphic_L is Î Î \Piroman_Î , and we assume that each relation symbol pğ‘pitalic_p has an unique arity, denoted aâ¢râ¢iâ¢tâ¢yâ¢(p)ğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘–ğ‘¡ğ‘¦ğ‘arity(p)italic_a italic_r italic_i italic_t italic_y ( italic_p ). Tâ¢Uâ„’ğ‘‡subscriptğ‘ˆâ„’TU_{\cal L}italic_T italic_U start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (resp. Tâ¢Bâ„’ğ‘‡subscriptğµâ„’TB_{\cal L}italic_T italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) denotes the set of all (ground and non ground) terms of â„’â„’{\cal L}caligraphic_L (resp. atoms of â„’â„’{\cal L}caligraphic_L). A query is a finite sequence of atoms A1,â€¦,Ansubscriptğ´1â€¦subscriptğ´ğ‘›A_{1},\ldots,A_{n}italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (where nâ‰¥0ğ‘›0n\geq 0italic_n â‰¥ 0). Queries are denoted by Qğ‘„Qitalic_Q, Qâ€²superscriptğ‘„â€²Q^{\prime}italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, â€¦ or by bold upper-case letters A, B, â€¦

Let tğ‘¡titalic_t be a term. Then Vâ¢aâ¢râ¢(t)ğ‘‰ğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘¡Var(t)italic_V italic_a italic_r ( italic_t ) denotes the set of variables occurring in tğ‘¡titalic_t. This notation is extended to atoms, queries and clauses. Let Î¸:={x1/t1,â€¦,xn/tn}assignğœƒsubscriptğ‘¥1subscriptğ‘¡1â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘›\theta:=\{x_{1}/t_{1},\ldots,x_{n}/t_{n}\}italic_Î¸ := { italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } be a substitution. We denote by Dâ¢oâ¢mâ¢(Î¸)ğ·ğ‘œğ‘šğœƒDom(\theta)italic_D italic_o italic_m ( italic_Î¸ ) the set of variables {x1,â€¦,xn}subscriptğ‘¥1â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›\{x_{1},\ldots,x_{n}\}{ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT }, and by Râ¢aâ¢nâ¢(Î¸)ğ‘…ğ‘ğ‘›ğœƒRan(\theta)italic_R italic_a italic_n ( italic_Î¸ ) the set of variables appearing in t1,â€¦,tnsubscriptğ‘¡1â€¦subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘›t_{1},\ldots,t_{n}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We define Vâ¢aâ¢râ¢(Î¸)=Dâ¢oâ¢mâ¢(Î¸)âˆªRâ¢aâ¢nâ¢(Î¸)ğ‘‰ğ‘ğ‘Ÿğœƒğ·ğ‘œğ‘šğœƒğ‘…ğ‘ğ‘›ğœƒVar(\theta)=Dom(\theta)\cup Ran(\theta)italic_V italic_a italic_r ( italic_Î¸ ) = italic_D italic_o italic_m ( italic_Î¸ ) âˆª italic_R italic_a italic_n ( italic_Î¸ ). Given a set of variables Vğ‘‰Vitalic_V, Î¸|Vconditionalğœƒğ‘‰\theta|Vitalic_Î¸ | italic_V denotes the substitution obtained from Î¸ğœƒ\thetaitalic_Î¸ by restricting its domain to Vğ‘‰Vitalic_V.

Let tğ‘¡titalic_t be a term and Î¸ğœƒ\thetaitalic_Î¸ be a substitution. Then, the term tâ¢Î¸ğ‘¡ğœƒt\thetaitalic_t italic_Î¸ is called an instance of tğ‘¡titalic_t. If Î¸ğœƒ\thetaitalic_Î¸ is a renaming (i.e. a substitution that is a 1-1 and onto mapping from its domain to itself), then tâ¢Î¸ğ‘¡ğœƒt\thetaitalic_t italic_Î¸ is called a variant of tğ‘¡titalic_t. Finally, tğ‘¡titalic_t is called more general than tâ€²superscriptğ‘¡normal-â€²t^{\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT if tâ€²superscriptğ‘¡â€²t^{\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is an instance of tğ‘¡titalic_t.

A logic program is a finite set of definite clauses. In program examples, we use the ISO-Prolog syntax. Let Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P be a logic program. Then Î PsubscriptÎ ğ‘ƒ\Pi_{P}roman_Î  start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT denotes the set of relation symbols appearing in Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P. Consider a non-empty query ğ€,B,ğ‚ğ€ğµğ‚\textup{\bf A},B,\textup{\bf C}A , italic_B , C and a clause cğ‘citalic_c. Let Hâ†ğâ†ğ»ğH\leftarrow\mathbf{B}italic_H â† bold_B be a variant of cğ‘citalic_c variable disjoint with ğ€,B,ğ‚ğ€ğµğ‚\textup{\bf A},B,\textup{\bf C}A , italic_B , C and assume that BğµBitalic_B and Hğ»Hitalic_H unify. Let Î¸ğœƒ\thetaitalic_Î¸ be an mgu of BğµBitalic_B and Hğ»Hitalic_H. Then ğ€,B,ğ‚â¢âŸ¹cÎ¸(ğ€,ğ,ğ‚)â¢Î¸ğ€ğµğ‚superscriptsubscriptâŸ¹ğ‘ğœƒğ€ğğ‚ğœƒ\textup{\bf A},B,\textup{\bf C}\mathop{\Longrightarrow}\limits_{c}^{\theta}(\textup{\bf A},\mathbf{B},\textup{\bf C})\thetaA , italic_B , C âŸ¹ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( A , bold_B , C ) italic_Î¸ is an SLD-derivation step with Hâ†ğâ†ğ»ğH\leftarrow\mathbf{B}italic_H â† bold_B as its input clause and BğµBitalic_B as its selected atom. If the substitution Î¸ğœƒ\thetaitalic_Î¸ or the clause cğ‘citalic_c is irrelevant, we drop a reference to it.

Let Q0subscriptğ‘„0Q_{0}italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be a query. A maximal sequence Q0â¢âŸ¹c1Î¸1Q1â¢âŸ¹c2Î¸2â‹¯subscriptğ‘„0superscriptsubscriptâŸ¹subscriptğ‘1subscriptğœƒ1subscriptğ‘„1superscriptsubscriptâŸ¹subscriptğ‘2subscriptğœƒ2â‹¯Q_{0}\mathop{\Longrightarrow}\limits_{c_{1}}^{\theta_{1}}Q_{1}\mathop{\Longrightarrow}\limits_{c_{2}}^{\theta_{2}}\cdotsitalic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ¹ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ¹ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹¯ of SLD-derivation steps is called an SLD-derivation of Pâˆª{Q0}ğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘„0P\cup\{Q_{0}\}italic_P âˆª { italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } if c1subscriptğ‘1c_{1}italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, c2subscriptğ‘2c_{2}italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, â€¦are clauses of Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P and if the standardization apart condition holds, i.e.: each input clause used is variable disjoint from the initial query Q0subscriptğ‘„0Q_{0}italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and from the mguâ€™s and input clauses used at earlier steps. A finite SLD-derivation may end up either with the empty query (then it is a successful SLD-derivation) or with a non-empty query (then it is a failed SLD-derivation). We say Q0subscriptğ‘„0Q_{0}italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT loops with respect to Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P if there exists an infinite SLD-derivation of Pâˆª{Q0}ğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘„0P\cup\{Q_{0}\}italic_P âˆª { italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT }.

Finally, we write Qâ¢âŸ¹P*Qâ€²ğ‘„superscriptsubscriptâŸ¹ğ‘ƒsuperscriptğ‘„â€²Q\mathop{\Longrightarrow}\limits_{P}^{*}Q^{\prime}italic_Q âŸ¹ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (resp. Qâ¢âŸ¹P+Qâ€²ğ‘„superscriptsubscriptâŸ¹ğ‘ƒsuperscriptğ‘„â€²Q\mathop{\Longrightarrow}\limits_{P}^{+}Q^{\prime}italic_Q âŸ¹ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT) if there exists a finite prefix (resp. a finite non-empty prefix) ending at Qâ€²superscriptğ‘„â€²Q^{\prime}italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT of an SLD-derivation of Pâˆª{Q}ğ‘ƒğ‘„P\cup\{Q\}italic_P âˆª { italic_Q }.

Let Eğ¸Eitalic_E and Fğ¹Fitalic_F be two sets. Then, f:Eâ†’F:ğ‘“â†’ğ¸ğ¹f:E\rightarrow Fitalic_f : italic_E â†’ italic_F denotes that fğ‘“fitalic_f is a function from Eğ¸Eitalic_E to Fğ¹Fitalic_F and f:Eâ†£F:ğ‘“â†£ğ¸ğ¹f:E\rightarrowtail Fitalic_f : italic_E â†£ italic_F denotes that fğ‘“fitalic_f is a mapping from Eğ¸Eitalic_E to Fğ¹Fitalic_F. The domain of a function fğ‘“fitalic_f from Eğ¸Eitalic_E to Fğ¹Fitalic_F is denoted by Dâ¢oâ¢mâ¢(f)ğ·ğ‘œğ‘šğ‘“Dom(f)italic_D italic_o italic_m ( italic_f ) and is defined as: Dâ¢oâ¢mâ¢(f)={x|xâˆˆE,fâ¢(x)â¢Â exists}ğ·ğ‘œğ‘šğ‘“conditional-setğ‘¥ğ‘¥ğ¸ğ‘“ğ‘¥Â existsDom(f)=\{x\;|\;x\in E,\;f(x)\text{ exists}\}italic_D italic_o italic_m ( italic_f ) = { italic_x | italic_x âˆˆ italic_E , italic_f ( italic_x ) exists }. Thus, if fğ‘“fitalic_f is a mapping from Eğ¸Eitalic_E to Fğ¹Fitalic_F, then Dâ¢oâ¢mâ¢(f)=Eğ·ğ‘œğ‘šğ‘“ğ¸Dom(f)=Eitalic_D italic_o italic_m ( italic_f ) = italic_E.

3 Neutral Arguments for SLD-Derivation

The basic idea in the work we present here relies on some arguments in clauses which we can be disregarded when unfolding a query. For instance, the second argument of the non-unit clause of the program

    append([],Ys,Ys).
    append([X|Xs],Ys,[X|Zs]) :- append(Xs,Ys,Zs).

is such a candidate. Notice that a very common programming technique called accumulator passing (see for instance e.g. [15], p. 21â€“25), always produces such patterns.

Example 3

A classical example of the accumulator passing technique is the following program REVERSE.

    reverse(L,R) :- rev(L,[],R).
    rev([],R,R).
    rev([X|Xs],R0,R) :- rev(Xs,[X|R0],R).

Concerning termination, we may ignore the third and the second argument of the recursive clause of rev while unfolding a query with this clause. Only the first argument can stop the unfolding. âˆ

But we can be more precise. Instead of only identifying arguments that can be totaly disregarded as in the above examples, we can try to identify arguments that can be replaced, when unfolding a query, by any terms for which a given condition holds. Consider for instance the program

    p(x,f(z)) :- q(x,y), p(y,f(z)).

If we unfold a query pâ¢(t1,t2)ğ‘subscriptğ‘¡1subscriptğ‘¡2p(t_{1},t_{2})italic_p ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) with this program, then if we replace the second argument of pğ‘pitalic_p by any instance t3subscriptğ‘¡3t_{3}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of fâ¢(z)ğ‘“ğ‘§f(z)italic_f ( italic_z ), we can still unfold pâ¢(t1,t3)ğ‘subscriptğ‘¡1subscriptğ‘¡3p(t_{1},t_{3})italic_p ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ).

In the sequel of this section, we give a technical tool to describe specific arguments inside a program and present an extension of the relation â€œis more general thanâ€. Then we formalize the concept of derivation neutrality and we propose an extended version of the Lifting TheoremÂ 1.1.

3.1 Filters

Let us first introduce the notion of a filter. We use filters in order to distinguish atoms some arguments of which satisfy a given condition. A condition upon atom arguments, i.e. terms, can be defined as a mapping in the following way.

Definition 1 (Term-Condition)

A term-condition is a mapping from Tâ¢Uâ„’ğ‘‡subscriptğ‘ˆâ„’TU_{\mathcal{L}}italic_T italic_U start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to {ğšğš›ğšğš,ğšğšŠğš•ğšœğš}ğšğš›ğšğšğšğšŠğš•ğšœğš\{\mathtt{true},\mathtt{false}\}{ typewriter_true , typewriter_false }.

Example 4

The following mappings are term-conditions.

fğ‘¡ğ‘Ÿğ‘¢ğ‘’:Tâ¢Uâ„’â†£{ğšğš›ğšğš,ğšğšŠğš•ğšœğš}tâ†¦ğšğš›ğšğšf1:Tâ¢Uâ„’â†£{ğšğš›ğšğš,ğšğšŠğš•ğšœğš}tâ†¦ğšğš›ğšğšÂ iffÂ tÂ is an instance ofÂ [x|y]f2:Tâ¢Uâ„’â†£{ğšğš›ğšğš,ğšğšŠğš•ğšœğš}tâ†¦ğšğš›ğšğšÂ iffÂ tÂ unifies withÂ hâ¢(a,x):subscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡ğ‘Ÿğ‘¢ğ‘’absentğ‘‡subscriptğ‘ˆâ„’â†£ğšğš›ğšğšğšğšŠğš•ğšœğšmissing-subexpressionğ‘¡maps-toğšğš›ğšğš:subscriptğ‘“1absentğ‘‡subscriptğ‘ˆâ„’â†£ğšğš›ğšğšğšğšŠğš•ğšœğšmissing-subexpressionğ‘¡maps-toğšğš›ğšğšÂ iffÂ tÂ is an instance ofÂ [x|y]:subscriptğ‘“2absentğ‘‡subscriptğ‘ˆâ„’â†£ğšğš›ğšğšğšğšŠğš•ğšœğšmissing-subexpressionğ‘¡maps-toğšğš›ğšğšÂ iffÂ tÂ unifies withÂ hâ¢(a,x)\begin{array}[]{rccl}f_{\mathit{true}}:&TU_{\mathcal{L}}&\rightarrowtail&\{\texttt{true},\texttt{false}\}\\ &t&\mapsto&\texttt{true}\\[8.61108pt] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_true end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : end_CELL start_CELL italic_T italic_U start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL start_CELL â†£ end_CELL start_CELL { true , false start_CELL end_CELL start_CELL italic_t end_CELL start_CELL â†¦ end_CELL start_CELL typewriter_true iff t unifies with h(a,x) end_CELL end_ROW end_ARRAY

Now we can precise what we exactly mean by a filter.

Definition 2 (Filter)

A filter, denoted by Î”Î”\Deltaroman_Î”, is a mapping from Î Î \Piroman_Î  such that: for each pâˆˆÎ ğ‘Î p\in\Piitalic_p âˆˆ roman_Î , Î”â¢(p)Î”ğ‘\Delta(p)roman_Î” ( italic_p ) is a function from [1,aâ¢râ¢iâ¢tâ¢yâ¢(p)]1ğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘–ğ‘¡ğ‘¦ğ‘[1,arity(p)][ 1 , italic_a italic_r italic_i italic_t italic_y ( italic_p ) ] to the set of term-conditions.

Example 5 (ExampleÂ 4 continued)

Let Î :={p}assignÎ ğ‘\Pi:=\{p\}roman_Î  := { italic_p } with pğ‘pitalic_p a relation symbol whose arity equals 3. Then, Î”:=âŸ¨pâ†¦âŸ¨1â†¦fğ‘¡ğ‘Ÿğ‘¢ğ‘’,â€„2â†¦f1âŸ©âŸ©assignÎ”delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©maps-toğ‘delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©formulae-sequencemaps-to1subscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡ğ‘Ÿğ‘¢ğ‘’maps-to2subscriptğ‘“1\Delta:=\langle\;p\mapsto\langle 1\mapsto f_{\mathit{true}},\;2\mapsto f_{1}\rangle\;\rangleroman_Î” := âŸ¨ italic_p â†¦ âŸ¨ 1 â†¦ italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_true end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , 2 â†¦ italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ© âŸ© is a filter. âˆ

Notice that, given a filter Î”Î”\Deltaroman_Î”, the relation â€œis more general thanâ€ can be extended in the following way: an atom A:=pâ¢(â‹¯)assignğ´ğ‘â‹¯A:=p(\cdots)italic_A := italic_p ( â‹¯ ) is Î”Î”\Deltaroman_Î”-more general than B:=pâ¢(â‹¯)assignğµğ‘â‹¯B:=p(\cdots)italic_B := italic_p ( â‹¯ ) if the â€œis more general thanâ€ requirement holds for those arguments of Ağ´Aitalic_A whose position is not in the domain of Î”â¢(p)Î”ğ‘\Delta(p)roman_Î” ( italic_p ) while the other arguments satisfy their associated term-condition.

Definition 3 (Î”normal-Î”\Deltaroman_Î”-More General)

Let Î”Î”\Deltaroman_Î” be a filter, Ağ´Aitalic_A and BğµBitalic_B be two atoms and Q:=A1,â€¦,Anassignğ‘„subscriptğ´1â€¦subscriptğ´ğ‘›Q:=A_{1},\dots,A_{n}italic_Q := italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Qâ€²:=B1,â€¦,Bmassignsuperscriptğ‘„â€²subscriptğµ1â€¦subscriptğµğ‘šQ^{\prime}:=B_{1},\dots,B_{m}italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT := italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be two queries.

    {A=pâ¢(s1,â€¦,sn)B=pâ¢(t1,â€¦,tn)âˆ€iâˆˆ[1,n]âˆ–Dâ¢oâ¢mâ¢(Î”â¢(p)),ti=siâ¢Î·âˆ€iâˆˆDâ¢oâ¢mâ¢(Î”â¢(p)),Î”â¢(p)â¢(i)â¢(si)=ğšğš›ğšğš.casesğ´ğ‘subscriptğ‘ 1â€¦subscriptğ‘ ğ‘›ğµğ‘subscriptğ‘¡1â€¦subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘›formulae-sequencefor-allğ‘–1ğ‘›ğ·ğ‘œğ‘šÎ”ğ‘subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ ğ‘–ğœ‚formulae-sequencefor-allğ‘–ğ·ğ‘œğ‘šÎ”ğ‘Î”ğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ ğ‘–ğšğš›ğšğš\left\{\begin{array}[]{l}A=p(s_{1},\dots,s_{n})\\ B=p(t_{1},\dots,t_{n})\\ \forall i\in[1,n]\setminus Dom(\Delta(p)),\;t_{i}=s_{i}\eta\\ \forall i\in Dom(\Delta(p)),\;\Delta(p)(i)(s_{i})=\mathtt{true}\,.\end{array}\right.{ start_ARRAY start_ROW start_CELL italic_A = italic_p ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL italic_B = italic_p ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL âˆ€ italic_i âˆˆ [ 1 , italic_n ] âˆ– italic_D italic_o italic_m ( roman_Î” ( italic_p ) ) , italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î· end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL âˆ€ italic_i âˆˆ italic_D italic_o italic_m ( roman_Î” ( italic_p ) ) , roman_Î” ( italic_p ) ( italic_i ) ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = typewriter_true . end_CELL end_ROW end_ARRAY

  • â€¢

    Qğ‘„Qitalic_Q is Î”normal-Î”\Deltaroman_Î”-more general than Qâ€²superscriptğ‘„normal-â€²Q^{\prime}italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT if there exists a substitution Î·ğœ‚\etaitalic_Î· s.t. Example 6

  • â€¢

    Consider the filter Î”Î”\Deltaroman_Î” defined in ExampleÂ 5. Then, Ağ´Aitalic_A is not Î”Î”\Deltaroman_Î”-more general than BğµBitalic_B and Cğ¶Citalic_C because, for instance, its second argument xğ‘¥xitalic_x is not an instance of [x|y]delimited-[]conditionalğ‘¥ğ‘¦[x|y][ italic_x | italic_y ] as required by f1subscriptğ‘“1f_{1}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.   • â€¢

    Consider the term-conditions defined in ExampleÂ 4. Let Î”â€²:=âŸ¨pâ†¦âŸ¨1â†¦fğ‘¡ğ‘Ÿğ‘¢ğ‘’,â€„2â†¦f1,â€„3â†¦f2âŸ©âŸ©assignsuperscriptÎ”â€²delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©maps-toğ‘delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©formulae-sequencemaps-to1subscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡ğ‘Ÿğ‘¢ğ‘’formulae-sequencemaps-to2subscriptğ‘“1maps-to3subscriptğ‘“2\Delta^{\prime}:=\langle\;p\mapsto\langle 1\mapsto f_{\mathit{true}},\;2\mapsto f_{1},\;3\mapsto f_{2}\rangle\;\rangleroman_Î” start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT := âŸ¨ italic_p â†¦ âŸ¨ 1 â†¦ italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_true end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , 2 â†¦ italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , 3 â†¦ italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ© âŸ©. Then, Ağ´Aitalic_A is not Î”â€²superscriptÎ”â€²\Delta^{\prime}roman_Î” start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT-more general than BğµBitalic_B and Cğ¶Citalic_C for the same reason as above. On the other hand, BğµBitalic_B is Î”â€²superscriptÎ”â€²\Delta^{\prime}roman_Î” start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT-more general than Ağ´Aitalic_A and Cğ¶Citalic_C for any substitution and Cğ¶Citalic_C is Î”â€²superscriptÎ”â€²\Delta^{\prime}roman_Î” start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT-more general than Ağ´Aitalic_A and BğµBitalic_B for any substitution. âˆ

The following proposition states an intuitive result:

Proposition 1

Let Î”normal-Î”\Deltaroman_Î” be a filter and Qğ‘„Qitalic_Q and Qâ€²superscriptğ‘„normal-â€²Q^{\prime}italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be two queries. Then Qğ‘„Qitalic_Q is Î”normal-Î”\Deltaroman_Î”-more general than Qâ€²superscriptğ‘„normal-â€²Q^{\prime}italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT if and only if there exists a substitution Î·ğœ‚\etaitalic_Î· such that Vâ¢aâ¢râ¢(Î·)âŠ†Vâ¢aâ¢râ¢(Q,Qâ€²)ğ‘‰ğ‘ğ‘Ÿğœ‚ğ‘‰ğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘„superscriptğ‘„normal-â€²Var(\eta)\subseteq Var(Q,Q^{\prime})italic_V italic_a italic_r ( italic_Î· ) âŠ† italic_V italic_a italic_r ( italic_Q , italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) and Qğ‘„Qitalic_Q is Î”normal-Î”\Deltaroman_Î”-more general than Qâ€²superscriptğ‘„normal-â€²Q^{\prime}italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for Î·ğœ‚\etaitalic_Î·.

Proof

The proof of this proposition is given in Appendix 1. âˆ

3.2 Derivation Neutral Filters: Operational Definition

Before we give a precise definition of the kind of filters we are interested in, we review the notion of a lift. The definition we propose below is the same as that of [1] p. 57 up to the arguments whose position is distinguished by a filter.

Definition 4 (Î”normal-Î”\Deltaroman_Î”-Lift)

Let Î”Î”\Deltaroman_Î” be a filter. Consider a sequence of SLD-derivation steps

Î¾:=Q0â¢âŸ¹c1Q1â¢â‹¯â¢Qnâ¢âŸ¹cn+1Qn+1â¢â‹¯assignğœ‰subscriptğ‘„0subscriptâŸ¹subscriptğ‘1subscriptğ‘„1â‹¯subscriptğ‘„ğ‘›subscriptâŸ¹subscriptğ‘ğ‘›1subscriptğ‘„ğ‘›1â‹¯\xi:=Q_{0}\mathop{\Longrightarrow}\limits_{c_{1}}Q_{1}\cdots Q_{n}\mathop{\Longrightarrow}\limits_{c_{n+1}}Q_{n+1}\cdotsitalic_Î¾ := italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ¹ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹¯ italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ¹ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹¯

We say that the sequence of SLD-derivation steps

Î¾â€²:=Q0â€²â¢âŸ¹c1Q1â€²â¢â‹¯â¢Qnâ€²â¢âŸ¹cn+1Qn+1â€²â¢â‹¯assignsuperscriptğœ‰â€²subscriptsuperscriptğ‘„â€²0subscriptâŸ¹subscriptğ‘1subscriptsuperscriptğ‘„â€²1â‹¯subscriptsuperscriptğ‘„â€²ğ‘›subscriptâŸ¹subscriptğ‘ğ‘›1subscriptsuperscriptğ‘„â€²ğ‘›1â‹¯\xi^{\prime}:=Q^{\prime}_{0}\mathop{\Longrightarrow}\limits_{c_{1}}Q^{\prime}_{1}\cdots Q^{\prime}_{n}\mathop{\Longrightarrow}\limits_{c_{n+1}}Q^{\prime}_{n+1}\cdotsitalic_Î¾ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT := italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ¹ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹¯ italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ¹ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹¯

is a Î”normal-Î”\Deltaroman_Î”-lift of Î¾ğœ‰\xiitalic_Î¾ if

  • â€¢

    Î¾ğœ‰\xiitalic_Î¾ is of the same or smaller length than Î¾â€²superscriptğœ‰â€²\xi^{\prime}italic_Î¾ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT,

  • â€¢

    for each Qisubscriptğ‘„ğ‘–Q_{i}italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in Î¾ğœ‰\xiitalic_Î¾, Qiâ€²subscriptsuperscriptğ‘„â€²ğ‘–Q^{\prime}_{i}italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is Î”Î”\Deltaroman_Î”-more general than Qisubscriptğ‘„ğ‘–Q_{i}italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT,

  • â€¢

    for each Qisubscriptğ‘„ğ‘–Q_{i}italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in Î¾ğœ‰\xiitalic_Î¾, in Qisubscriptğ‘„ğ‘–Q_{i}italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Qiâ€²subscriptsuperscriptğ‘„â€²ğ‘–Q^{\prime}_{i}italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT atoms in the same positions are selected.

In the sequel of this paper, we focus on â€œderivation neutralâ€ filters. The name â€œderivation neutralâ€ stems from the fact that in any derivation of a query Qğ‘„Qitalic_Q, the arguments of Qğ‘„Qitalic_Q whose position is distinguished by such a filter can be safely replaced by any terms satisfying the associated term-condition. Such a replacement does not modify the derivation process.

Definition 5 (Derivation Neutral)

Let Î”Î”\Deltaroman_Î” be a filter and cğ‘citalic_c be a clause. We say that Î”normal-Î”\Deltaroman_Î” is DN for cğ‘citalic_c if

  • â€¢

    for each SLD-derivation step Qâ¢âŸ¹cQ1ğ‘„subscriptâŸ¹ğ‘subscriptğ‘„1Q\mathop{\Longrightarrow}\limits_{c}Q_{1}italic_Q âŸ¹ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT,

  • â€¢

    for each query Qâ€²superscriptğ‘„â€²Q^{\prime}italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT that is Î”Î”\Deltaroman_Î”-more general than Qğ‘„Qitalic_Q,

there exists a query Q1â€²subscriptsuperscriptğ‘„â€²1Q^{\prime}_{1}italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT such that Qâ€²â¢âŸ¹cQ1â€²superscriptğ‘„â€²subscriptâŸ¹ğ‘subscriptsuperscriptğ‘„â€²1Q^{\prime}\mathop{\Longrightarrow}\limits_{c}Q^{\prime}_{1}italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŸ¹ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Qâ€²â¢âŸ¹cQ1â€²superscriptğ‘„â€²subscriptâŸ¹ğ‘subscriptsuperscriptğ‘„â€²1Q^{\prime}\mathop{\Longrightarrow}\limits_{c}Q^{\prime}_{1}italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŸ¹ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a Î”Î”\Deltaroman_Î”-lift of Qâ¢âŸ¹cQ1ğ‘„subscriptâŸ¹ğ‘subscriptğ‘„1Q\mathop{\Longrightarrow}\limits_{c}Q_{1}italic_Q âŸ¹ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

This definition is extended to finite sets of clauses: Î”normal-Î”\Deltaroman_Î” is DN for a logic program Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P if it is DN for each clause of Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P.

Example 7

The following examples illustrate the above definitions.

  • â€¢

    Consider the following program APPEND:

          append([],Xs,Xs).                              % C1
      append([X|Xs],Ys,[X|Zs]) :- append(Xs,Ys,Zs).  % C2

    Consider the term-condition fğ‘¡ğ‘Ÿğ‘¢ğ‘’subscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡ğ‘Ÿğ‘¢ğ‘’f_{\mathit{true}}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_true end_POSTSUBSCRIPT defined in ExampleÂ 4, the set of relation symbols Î :={aâ¢pâ¢pâ¢eâ¢nâ¢d}assignÎ ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘’ğ‘›ğ‘‘\Pi:=\{append\}roman_Î  := { italic_a italic_p italic_p italic_e italic_n italic_d } and the filter Î”:=âŸ¨aâ¢pâ¢pâ¢eâ¢nâ¢dâ†¦âŸ¨2â†¦fğ‘¡ğ‘Ÿğ‘¢ğ‘’âŸ©âŸ©assignÎ”delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©maps-toğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘’ğ‘›ğ‘‘delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©maps-to2subscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡ğ‘Ÿğ‘¢ğ‘’\Delta:=\langle append\mapsto\langle 2\mapsto f_{\mathit{true}}\rangle\rangleroman_Î” := âŸ¨ italic_a italic_p italic_p italic_e italic_n italic_d â†¦ âŸ¨ 2 â†¦ italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_true end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ© âŸ©. Then, Î”Î”\Deltaroman_Î” is DN for C2. However, Î”Î”\Deltaroman_Î” is not DN for APPEND because it is not DN for C1.

  • â€¢

    Consider the following program MERGE:

    merge([X|Xs],[Y|Ys],[X|Zs]) :- merge(Xs,[Y|Ys],Zs).

    Consider the term-condition f1subscriptğ‘“1f_{1}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT defined in ExampleÂ 4, the set of relation symbols Î :={mâ¢eâ¢râ¢gâ¢e}assignÎ ğ‘šğ‘’ğ‘Ÿğ‘”ğ‘’\Pi:=\{merge\}roman_Î  := { italic_m italic_e italic_r italic_g italic_e } and the filter Î”:=âŸ¨mâ¢eâ¢râ¢gâ¢eâ†¦âŸ¨2â†¦f1âŸ©âŸ©assignÎ”delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©maps-toğ‘šğ‘’ğ‘Ÿğ‘”ğ‘’delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©maps-to2subscriptğ‘“1\Delta:=\langle merge\mapsto\langle 2\mapsto f_{1}\rangle\rangleroman_Î” := âŸ¨ italic_m italic_e italic_r italic_g italic_e â†¦ âŸ¨ 2 â†¦ italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ© âŸ©. Then, Î”Î”\Deltaroman_Î” is DN for MERGE. âˆ

Repeatedly using this definition, we get an extended version of the Lifting TheoremÂ 1.1.

Theorem 3.1 (Î”normal-Î”\Deltaroman_Î”-Lifting)

Let Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P be a logic program and Î”normal-Î”\Deltaroman_Î” be a DN filter for Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P. Let Î¾ğœ‰\xiitalic_Î¾ be an SLD-derivation of Pâˆª{Q0}ğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘„0P\cup\{Q_{0}\}italic_P âˆª { italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } and Q0â€²subscriptsuperscriptğ‘„normal-â€²0Q^{\prime}_{0}italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be a query that is Î”normal-Î”\Deltaroman_Î”-more general than Q0subscriptğ‘„0Q_{0}italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Then there exists an SLD-derivation of Pâˆª{Q0â€²}ğ‘ƒsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘„normal-â€²0P\cup\{Q^{\prime}_{0}\}italic_P âˆª { italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } that is a Î”normal-Î”\Deltaroman_Î”-lift of Î¾ğœ‰\xiitalic_Î¾.

Proof

If Î¾ğœ‰\xiitalic_Î¾ is infinite, we can construct a required SLD-derivation Î¾â€²superscriptğœ‰â€²\xi^{\prime}italic_Î¾ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT whose length is infinite by repeatedly using DefinitionÂ 5.

Now if Î¾ğœ‰\xiitalic_Î¾ is of finite length, then

  • â€¢

    either Î¾ğœ‰\xiitalic_Î¾ is successful: in this case, we can construct a required SLD-derivation Î¾â€²superscriptğœ‰â€²\xi^{\prime}italic_Î¾ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT of the same length than Î¾ğœ‰\xiitalic_Î¾ by repeatedly using DefinitionÂ 5,

  • â€¢

    either Î¾ğœ‰\xiitalic_Î¾ fails. Suppose that Î¾:=Q0â¢âŸ¹c1Q1â¢â‹¯â¢Qnâ¢âŸ¹cn+1Qn+1assignğœ‰subscriptğ‘„0subscriptâŸ¹subscriptğ‘1subscriptğ‘„1â‹¯subscriptğ‘„ğ‘›subscriptâŸ¹subscriptğ‘ğ‘›1subscriptğ‘„ğ‘›1\xi:=Q_{0}\mathop{\Longrightarrow}\limits_{c_{1}}Q_{1}\cdots Q_{n}\mathop{\Longrightarrow}\limits_{c_{n+1}}Q_{n+1}italic_Î¾ := italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ¹ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹¯ italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ¹ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Then, by repeatedly using DefinitionÂ 5, we can construct a finite sequence of SLD-derivation steps

    Q0â€²â¢âŸ¹c1Q1â€²â¢â‹¯â¢Qnâ€²â¢âŸ¹cn+1Qn+1â€²subscriptsuperscriptğ‘„â€²0subscriptâŸ¹subscriptğ‘1subscriptsuperscriptğ‘„â€²1â‹¯subscriptsuperscriptğ‘„â€²ğ‘›subscriptâŸ¹subscriptğ‘ğ‘›1subscriptsuperscriptğ‘„â€²ğ‘›1Q^{\prime}_{0}\mathop{\Longrightarrow}\limits_{c_{1}}Q^{\prime}_{1}\cdots Q^{\prime}_{n}\mathop{\Longrightarrow}\limits_{c_{n+1}}Q^{\prime}_{n+1}italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ¹ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹¯ italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ¹ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT

    that is a Î”Î”\Deltaroman_Î”-lift of Î¾ğœ‰\xiitalic_Î¾. But as Qn+1â€²subscriptsuperscriptğ‘„â€²ğ‘›1Q^{\prime}_{n+1}italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is Î”Î”\Deltaroman_Î”-more general than Qn+1subscriptğ‘„ğ‘›1Q_{n+1}italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, this sequence may not be a maximal one, i.e. from Qn+1â€²subscriptsuperscriptğ‘„â€²ğ‘›1Q^{\prime}_{n+1}italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P, we may derive Qn+2â€²subscriptsuperscriptğ‘„â€²ğ‘›2Q^{\prime}_{n+2}italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n + 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and so forth. Hence, in this case, there may exist an SLD-derivation of Pâˆª{Q0â€²}ğ‘ƒsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘„â€²0P\cup\{Q^{\prime}_{0}\}italic_P âˆª { italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } that is a Î”Î”\Deltaroman_Î”-lift of Î¾ğœ‰\xiitalic_Î¾ but of longer length than Î¾ğœ‰\xiitalic_Î¾. âˆ

3.3 Model Theoretic Results Induced by DN Filters

Lifting lemmas are used in the literature to prove completeness of SLD-resolution. Now that we have established an extended Lifting Theorem, it may be worth to investigate its consequences from the model theoretic point of view.

Let Eğ¸Eitalic_E be an atom or a query and Î”Î”\Deltaroman_Î” be a filter. Then one may â€œexpandâ€ the atoms occurring in Eğ¸Eitalic_E by replacing every argument whose position is distinguished by Î”Î”\Deltaroman_Î” by any term that satisfies the associated term-condition.

Definition 6 (Expansion of atoms and queries by a filter)

Let Î”Î”\Deltaroman_Î” be a filter.

  • â€¢

    Let Ağ´Aitalic_A be an atom. The expansion of Ağ´Aitalic_A w.r.t. Î”normal-Î”\Deltaroman_Î”, denoted [A]Î”superscriptdelimited-[]ğ´Î”[A]^{\Delta}[ italic_A ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Î” end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, is the set defined as

    [A]Î”:={BâˆˆTâ¢Bâ„’|Bâ¢Â isÂ Î”-more general thanÂ AÂ forÂ â¢Ïµ}assignsuperscriptdelimited-[]ğ´Î”conditional-setğµğ‘‡subscriptğµâ„’ğµÂ isÂ Î”-more general thanÂ AÂ forÂ italic-Ïµ[A]^{\Delta}:=\{B\in TB_{\mathcal{L}}\;|\;B\text{ is $\Delta$-more general than $A$ for }\epsilon\}[ italic_A ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Î” end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT := { italic_B âˆˆ italic_T italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_B is roman_Î” -more general than italic_A for italic_Ïµ }

    where Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ denotes the empty substitution.

  • â€¢

    Let Q:=A1,â€¦,Anassignğ‘„subscriptğ´1â€¦subscriptğ´ğ‘›Q:=A_{1},\dots,A_{n}italic_Q := italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be a query. The expansion of Qğ‘„Qitalic_Q w.r.t. Î”normal-Î”\Deltaroman_Î”, denoted [Q]Î”superscriptdelimited-[]ğ‘„Î”[Q]^{\Delta}[ italic_Q ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Î” end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, is the set defined as:

    [Q]Î”:={(B1,â€¦,Bn)|B1âˆˆ[A1]Î”,â€¦,Bnâˆˆ[An]Î”}.assignsuperscriptdelimited-[]ğ‘„Î”conditional-setsubscriptğµ1â€¦subscriptğµğ‘›formulae-sequencesubscriptğµ1superscriptdelimited-[]subscriptğ´1Î”â€¦subscriptğµğ‘›superscriptdelimited-[]subscriptğ´ğ‘›Î”[Q]^{\Delta}:=\{(B_{1},\dots,B_{n})\;|\;B_{1}\in[A_{1}]^{\Delta},\dots,B_{n}\in[A_{n}]^{\Delta}\}.[ italic_Q ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Î” end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT := { ( italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) | italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ [ italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Î” end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ [ italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Î” end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } .

Term interpretations in the context of logic programming were introduced inÂ [6] and further investigated inÂ [7] andÂ [12]. A term interpretation for â„’â„’\mathcal{L}caligraphic_L is identified with a (possibly empty) subset of the term base Tâ¢Bâ„’ğ‘‡subscriptğµâ„’TB_{\mathcal{L}}italic_T italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. So, as for atoms, a term interpretation can be expanded by a set of positions.

Definition 7 (Expansion of term interpretations by a filter)

Let Î”Î”\Deltaroman_Î” be a filter and Iğ¼Iitalic_I be a term interpretation for â„’â„’\mathcal{L}caligraphic_L. Then [I]Î”superscriptdelimited-[]ğ¼Î”[I]^{\Delta}[ italic_I ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Î” end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the term interpretation for â„’â„’\mathcal{L}caligraphic_L defined as:

[I]Î”:=â‹ƒAâˆˆI[A]Î”.assignsuperscriptdelimited-[]ğ¼Î”subscriptğ´ğ¼superscriptdelimited-[]ğ´Î”[I]^{\Delta}:=\bigcup_{A\in I}[A]^{\Delta}\;.[ italic_I ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Î” end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT := â‹ƒ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A âˆˆ italic_I end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_A ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Î” end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .

For any logic program Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P, we denote by ğ’â¢(P)ğ’ğ‘ƒ\mathcal{C}(P)caligraphic_C ( italic_P ) its least term model.

Theorem 3.2

Let Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P be a logic program and Î”normal-Î”\Deltaroman_Î” be a DN filter for Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P. Then [ğ’â¢(P)]Î”=ğ’â¢(P)superscriptdelimited-[]ğ’ğ‘ƒnormal-Î”ğ’ğ‘ƒ[\mathcal{C}(P)]^{\Delta}=\mathcal{C}(P)[ caligraphic_C ( italic_P ) ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Î” end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = caligraphic_C ( italic_P ).

Proof

The inclusion ğ’â¢(P)âŠ†[ğ’â¢(P)]Î”ğ’ğ‘ƒsuperscriptdelimited-[]ğ’ğ‘ƒÎ”\mathcal{C}(P)\subseteq[\mathcal{C}(P)]^{\Delta}caligraphic_C ( italic_P ) âŠ† [ caligraphic_C ( italic_P ) ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Î” end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is trivial so let us concentrate on the other one i.e. [ğ’â¢(P)]Î”âŠ†ğ’â¢(P)superscriptdelimited-[]ğ’ğ‘ƒÎ”ğ’ğ‘ƒ[\mathcal{C}(P)]^{\Delta}\subseteq\mathcal{C}(P)[ caligraphic_C ( italic_P ) ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Î” end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ† caligraphic_C ( italic_P ). Let Aâ€²âˆˆ[ğ’â¢(P)]Î”superscriptğ´â€²superscriptdelimited-[]ğ’ğ‘ƒÎ”A^{\prime}\in[\mathcal{C}(P)]^{\Delta}italic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ [ caligraphic_C ( italic_P ) ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Î” end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Then there exists Aâˆˆğ’â¢(P)ğ´ğ’ğ‘ƒA\in\mathcal{C}(P)italic_A âˆˆ caligraphic_C ( italic_P ) such that Aâ€²âˆˆ[A]Î”superscriptğ´â€²superscriptdelimited-[]ğ´Î”A^{\prime}\in[A]^{\Delta}italic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ [ italic_A ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Î” end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. A well known result states:

ğ’â¢(P)={BâˆˆTâ¢Bâ„’|there exists a successful SLD-derivation ofÂ â¢B}ğ’ğ‘ƒconditional-setğµğ‘‡subscriptğµâ„’there exists a successful SLD-derivation ofÂ ğµ\mathcal{C}(P)=\{B\in TB_{\mathcal{L}}\;|\;\text{there exists a successful SLD-derivation of }B\}caligraphic_C ( italic_P ) = { italic_B âˆˆ italic_T italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | there exists a successful SLD-derivation of italic_B } (1)

Consequently, there exists a successful SLD-derivation of Ağ´Aitalic_A. Therefore, by the Î”Î”\Deltaroman_Î”-Lifting TheoremÂ 3.1, there exists a successful SLD-derivation of Aâ€²superscriptğ´â€²A^{\prime}italic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. So byÂ (1) Aâ€²âˆˆğ’â¢(P)superscriptğ´â€²ğ’ğ‘ƒA^{\prime}\in\mathcal{C}(P)italic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ caligraphic_C ( italic_P ). âˆ

4 Some Particular DN Filters

In this section, we consider some instances of the definitions of SectionÂ 3.

4.1 DN Sets of Positions

The first instance we consider corresponds to filters whose associated term-conditions are all equal to fğ‘¡ğ‘Ÿğ‘¢ğ‘’subscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡ğ‘Ÿğ‘¢ğ‘’f_{\mathit{true}}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_true end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (see ExampleÂ 4.) Within such a context, as the term-conditions are fixed, each filter Î”Î”\Deltaroman_Î” is uniquely determined by the domains of the functions Î”â¢(p)Î”ğ‘\Delta(p)roman_Î” ( italic_p ) for pâˆˆÎ ğ‘Î p\in\Piitalic_p âˆˆ roman_Î . Hence the following definition.

Definition 8 (Set of Positions)

A set of positions, denoted by Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„, is a mapping from Î Î \Piroman_Î  to 2Nsuperscript2ğ‘2^{N}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT such that: for each pâˆˆÎ ğ‘Î p\in\Piitalic_p âˆˆ roman_Î , Ï„â¢(p)ğœğ‘\tau(p)italic_Ï„ ( italic_p ) is a subset of [1,aâ¢râ¢iâ¢tâ¢yâ¢(p)]1ğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘–ğ‘¡ğ‘¦ğ‘[1,arity(p)][ 1 , italic_a italic_r italic_i italic_t italic_y ( italic_p ) ].

Example 8

Then

Ï„:=âŸ¨ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘’ğ‘›ğ‘‘â†¦{2},append3â†¦{2,3}âŸ©assignğœdelimited-âŸ¨âŸ©formulae-sequencemaps-toğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘’ğ‘›ğ‘‘2maps-toitalic-append323\tau:=\langle\;\mathit{append}\mapsto\{2\},\;\mathit{append3}\mapsto\{2,3\}\;\rangleitalic_Ï„ := âŸ¨ italic_append â†¦ { 2 } , italic_append3 â†¦ { 2 , 3 } âŸ©

is a set of positions. âˆ

Not surprisingly, the filter that is generated by a set of positions is defined as follows.

Definition 9 (Associated Filter)

Let Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„ be a set of positions and fğ‘¡ğ‘Ÿğ‘¢ğ‘’subscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡ğ‘Ÿğ‘¢ğ‘’f_{\mathit{true}}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_true end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be the term-condition defined in ExampleÂ 4. The filter Î”â¢[Ï„]Î”delimited-[]ğœ\Delta[\tau]roman_Î” [ italic_Ï„ ] defined as:

for eachÂ â¢pâˆˆÎ ,Î”â¢[Ï„]â¢(p)â¢Â is the mapping fromÂ â¢Ï„â¢(p)â¢Â toÂ â¢{fğ‘¡ğ‘Ÿğ‘¢ğ‘’}for eachÂ ğ‘Î Î”delimited-[]ğœğ‘Â is the mapping fromÂ ğœğ‘Â toÂ subscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡ğ‘Ÿğ‘¢ğ‘’\textrm{for each }p\in\Pi,\;\Delta[\tau](p)\textrm{ is the mapping from }\tau(p)\textrm{ to }\{f_{\mathit{true}}\}for each italic_p âˆˆ roman_Î  , roman_Î” [ italic_Ï„ ] ( italic_p ) is the mapping from italic_Ï„ ( italic_p ) to { italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_true end_POSTSUBSCRIPT }

is called the filter associated to Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„.

Example 9 (ExampleÂ 8 continued)

The filter associated to Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„ is

Î”â¢[Ï„]:=âŸ¨ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘’ğ‘›ğ‘‘â†¦âŸ¨2â†¦fğ‘¡ğ‘Ÿğ‘¢ğ‘’âŸ©,append3â†¦âŸ¨2â†¦fğ‘¡ğ‘Ÿğ‘¢ğ‘’,â€„3â†¦fğ‘¡ğ‘Ÿğ‘¢ğ‘’âŸ©âŸ©.assignÎ”delimited-[]ğœdelimited-âŸ¨âŸ©formulae-sequencemaps-toğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘’ğ‘›ğ‘‘delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©maps-to2subscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡ğ‘Ÿğ‘¢ğ‘’maps-toitalic-append3delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©formulae-sequencemaps-to2subscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡ğ‘Ÿğ‘¢ğ‘’maps-to3subscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡ğ‘Ÿğ‘¢ğ‘’\Delta[\tau]:=\langle\;\mathit{append}\mapsto\langle 2\mapsto f_{\mathit{true}}\rangle,\;\mathit{append3}\mapsto\langle 2\mapsto f_{\mathit{true}},\;3\mapsto f_{\mathit{true}}\rangle\;\rangle\;.roman_Î” [ italic_Ï„ ] := âŸ¨ italic_append â†¦ âŸ¨ 2 â†¦ italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_true end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ© , italic_append3 â†¦ âŸ¨ 2 â†¦ italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_true end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , 3 â†¦ italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_true end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ© âŸ© .

Now we define a particular kind of sets of positions. These are named after â€œDNâ€ because, as stated by TheoremÂ 4.1 below, they generate DN filters.

Definition 10 (DN Set of Positions)

Let Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„ be a set of positions. We say that Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„ is DN for a clause pâ¢(s1,â€¦,sn)ğ‘subscriptğ‘ 1â€¦subscriptğ‘ ğ‘›p(s_{1},\dots,s_{n})italic_p ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) â†ğâ†absentğ\leftarrow\textup{\bf B}â† B if:

âˆ€iâˆˆÏ„â¢(p),{siâ¢Â is a variablesiâ¢Â occurs only once inÂ â¢pâ¢(s1,â€¦,sn)for eachÂ â¢qâ¢(t1,â€¦,tm)âˆˆğ:âˆ€jâˆˆ[1,m],siâˆˆVâ¢aâ¢râ¢(tj)â‡’jâˆˆÏ„â¢(q).for-allğ‘–ğœğ‘casessubscriptğ‘ ğ‘–Â is a variablesubscriptğ‘ ğ‘–Â occurs only once inÂ ğ‘subscriptğ‘ 1â€¦subscriptğ‘ ğ‘›:for eachÂ ğ‘subscriptğ‘¡1â€¦subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘šğabsentformulae-sequencefor-allğ‘—1ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘–ğ‘‰ğ‘ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘—â‡’ğ‘—ğœğ‘\forall i\in\tau(p),\;\left\{\begin{array}[]{l}s_{i}\text{ is a variable}\\ s_{i}\text{ occurs only once in }p(s_{1},\dots,s_{n})\\ \text{for each }q(t_{1},\dots,t_{m})\in\textup{\bf B}:\\ \hskip 14.22636pt\forall j\in[1,m],\;s_{i}\in Var(t_{j})\Rightarrow j\in\tau(q)\;.\end{array}\right.âˆ€ italic_i âˆˆ italic_Ï„ ( italic_p ) , { start_ARRAY start_ROW start_CELL italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a variable end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT occurs only once in italic_p ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL for each italic_q ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) âˆˆ B : end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL âˆ€ italic_j âˆˆ [ 1 , italic_m ] , italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ italic_V italic_a italic_r ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) â‡’ italic_j âˆˆ italic_Ï„ ( italic_q ) . end_CELL end_ROW end_ARRAY

A set of positions is DN for a program Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P if it is DN for each clause of Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P.

The intuition of DefinitionÂ 10 is the following. If for instance we have a clause c:=pâ¢(x,y,fâ¢(z))â†pâ¢(gâ¢(y,z),x,z)assignğ‘ğ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ‘“ğ‘§â†ğ‘ğ‘”ğ‘¦ğ‘§ğ‘¥ğ‘§c:=p(x,y,f(z))\leftarrow p(g(y,z),x,z)italic_c := italic_p ( italic_x , italic_y , italic_f ( italic_z ) ) â† italic_p ( italic_g ( italic_y , italic_z ) , italic_x , italic_z ) then in the first two positions of pğ‘pitalic_p we can put any terms and get a derivation step w.r.t. cğ‘citalic_c because the first two arguments of the head of cğ‘citalic_c are variables that appear exactly once in the head. Moreover, xğ‘¥xitalic_x and yğ‘¦yitalic_y of the head reappear in the body but again only in the first two positions of pğ‘pitalic_p. So, if we have a derivation step pâ¢(s1,s2,s3)â¢âŸ¹cpâ¢(t1,t2,t3)ğ‘subscriptğ‘ 1subscriptğ‘ 2subscriptğ‘ 3subscriptâŸ¹ğ‘ğ‘subscriptğ‘¡1subscriptğ‘¡2subscriptğ‘¡3p(s_{1},s_{2},s_{3})\mathop{\Longrightarrow}\limits_{c}p(t_{1},t_{2},t_{3})italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), we can replace s1subscriptğ‘ 1s_{1}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and s2subscriptğ‘ 2s_{2}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT by any terms end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) where t3â€²subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¡â€²3t^{\prime}_{3}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the same as t3subscriptğ‘¡3t_{3}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT up to variable names.

Example 10 (ExampleÂ 8 continued)

Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„ is DN for the following program:

  append([X|Xs],Ys,[X|Zs]) :- append(Xs,Ys,Zs).
  append3(Xs,Ys,Zs,Ts) :- append(Xs,Ys,Us), append(Us,Zs,Ts).

DN sets of positions generate DN filters.

Theorem 4.1

Let Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„ be a DN set of positions for a logic program Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P. Then Î”â¢[Ï„]normal-Î”delimited-[]ğœ\Delta[\tau]roman_Î” [ italic_Ï„ ] is DN for Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P.

Proof

See LemmaÂ 4 and TheoremÂ 4.2 further. âˆ

Notice that the set of DN sets of positions of a logic program is not empty as stated by the following proposition.

Proposition 2

Let Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P be a logic program. Then Ï„0:=âŸ¨pâ†¦âˆ…|pâˆˆÎ âŸ©assignsubscriptğœ0inner-productmaps-toğ‘ğ‘normal-Î \tau_{0}:=\langle p\mapsto\varnothing\;|\;p\in\Pi\rangleitalic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := âŸ¨ italic_p â†¦ âˆ… | italic_p âˆˆ roman_Î  âŸ© is DN for Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P.

Proof

By DefinitionÂ 10. âˆ

Moreover, an atom Ağ´Aitalic_A is Î”â¢[Ï„0]Î”delimited-[]subscriptğœ0\Delta[\tau_{0}]roman_Î” [ italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ]-more general than an atom BğµBitalic_B iff Ağ´Aitalic_A is more general than BğµBitalic_B. So, in the context of the filter Î”â¢[Ï„0]Î”delimited-[]subscriptğœ0\Delta[\tau_{0}]roman_Î” [ italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ], the Î”Î”\Deltaroman_Î”-Lifting TheoremÂ 3.1 is the same as the Lifting TheoremÂ 1.1.

4.2 DN Sets of Positions with Associated Terms

Now we consider another instance of the definitions of SectionÂ 3. As we will see, it is more general than the previous one. It corresponds to filters whose associated term-conditions have all the form â€œis an instance of tğ‘¡titalic_tâ€ where tğ‘¡titalic_t is a term that uniquely determines the term-condition. Hence the following definition.

Definition 11 (Sets of Positions with Associated Terms)

A set of positions with associated terms, denoted by Ï„+superscriptğœ\tau^{+}italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, is a mapping from Î Î \Piroman_Î  such that: for each pâˆˆÎ ğ‘Î p\in\Piitalic_p âˆˆ roman_Î , Ï„+â¢(p)superscriptğœğ‘\tau^{+}(p)italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_p ) is a function from [1,aâ¢râ¢iâ¢tâ¢yâ¢(p)]1ğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘–ğ‘¡ğ‘¦ğ‘[1,arity(p)][ 1 , italic_a italic_r italic_i italic_t italic_y ( italic_p ) ] to Tâ¢Uâ„’ğ‘‡subscriptğ‘ˆâ„’TU_{\mathcal{L}}italic_T italic_U start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Example 11

Let Î :={p,q}assignÎ ğ‘ğ‘\Pi:=\{p,q\}roman_Î  := { italic_p , italic_q } where the arity of pğ‘pitalic_p and qğ‘qitalic_q is 2. Then,

Ï„+:=âŸ¨pâ†¦âŸ¨2â†¦xâŸ©,qâ†¦âŸ¨2â†¦gâ¢(x)âŸ©âŸ©assignsuperscriptğœdelimited-âŸ¨âŸ©formulae-sequencemaps-toğ‘delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©maps-to2ğ‘¥maps-toğ‘delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©maps-to2ğ‘”ğ‘¥\tau^{+}:=\langle\;p\mapsto\langle 2\mapsto x\rangle,\;q\mapsto\langle 2\mapsto g(x)\rangle\;\rangleitalic_Ï„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT := âŸ¨ italic_p â†¦ âŸ¨ 2 â†¦ italic_x âŸ© , italic_q â†¦ âŸ¨ 2 â†¦ italic_g ( italic_x ) âŸ© âŸ©

is a set of positions with associated terms. âˆ

The filter that is generated by a set of positions with associated terms is defined as follows.

Definition 12 (Associated Filter)

Let Ï„+superscriptğœ\tau^{+}italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be a set of positions with associated terms. The filter associated to Ï„+superscriptğœ\tau^{+}italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, denoted by Î”â¢[Ï„+]Î”delimited-[]superscriptğœ\Delta[\tau^{+}]roman_Î” [ italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ], is defined as: for each pâˆˆÎ ğ‘Î p\in\Piitalic_p âˆˆ roman_Î , Î”â¢[Ï„+]â¢(p)Î”delimited-[]superscriptğœğ‘\Delta[\tau^{+}](p)roman_Î” [ italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] ( italic_p ) is the mapping

Dâ¢oâ¢mâ¢(Ï„+â¢(p))â†£The set of term-conditionsiâ†¦{Tâ¢Uâ„’â†£{ğšğš›ğšğš,ğšğšŠğš•ğšœğš}tâ†¦ğšğš›ğšğšâ¢Â iffÂ tÂ is an instance ofÂ â¢Ï„+â¢(p)â¢(i)ğ·ğ‘œğ‘šsuperscriptğœğ‘â†£The set of term-conditionsğ‘–maps-tocasesğ‘‡subscriptğ‘ˆâ„’â†£ğšğš›ğšğšğšğšŠğš•ğšœğšğ‘¡maps-toğšğš›ğšğšÂ iffÂ tÂ is an instance ofÂ superscriptğœğ‘ğ‘–\begin{array}[]{ccl}Dom(\tau^{+}(p))&\rightarrowtail&\text{The set of term-conditions}\\[4.30554pt] i&\mapsto&\left\{\begin{array}[]{ccl}TU_{\mathcal{L}}&\rightarrowtail&\{\mathtt{true},\mathtt{false}\}\\[4.30554pt] t&\mapsto&\mathtt{true}\text{ iff $t$ is an instance of }\tau^{+}(p)(i)\\ \end{array}\right.\end{array}start_ARRAY start_ROW start_CELL italic_D italic_o italic_m ( italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_p ) ) end_CELL start_CELL â†£ end_CELL start_CELL The set of term-conditions end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL italic_i end_CELL start_CELL â†¦ end_CELL start_CELL { start_ARRAY start_ROW start_CELL italic_T italic_U start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL start_CELL â†£ end_CELL start_CELL { typewriter_true , typewriter_false } end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL italic_t end_CELL start_CELL â†¦ end_CELL start_CELL typewriter_true iff italic_t is an instance of italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_p ) ( italic_i ) end_CELL end_ROW end_ARRAY end_CELL end_ROW end_ARRAY
Example 12 (ExampleÂ 11 continued)
