As for sets of positions, we define a special kind of sets of positions with associated terms.

Definition 13 (DN Sets of Positions with Associated Terms)

Let Ï„+superscriptğœ\tau^{+}italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be a set of positions with associated terms. We say that Ï„+superscriptğœ\tau^{+}italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is DN for a clause pâ¢(s1,â€¦,sn)â†ğâ†ğ‘subscriptğ‘ 1â€¦subscriptğ‘ ğ‘›ğp(s_{1},\dots,s_{n})\leftarrow\textup{\bf B}italic_p ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) â† B if these conditions hold:

  • â€¢

    (DN1) âˆ€iâˆˆDâ¢oâ¢mâ¢(Ï„+â¢(p))for-allğ‘–ğ·ğ‘œğ‘šsuperscriptğœğ‘\forall i\in Dom(\tau^{+}(p))âˆ€ italic_i âˆˆ italic_D italic_o italic_m ( italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_p ) ), âˆ€jâˆˆ[1,n]âˆ–{i}for-allğ‘—1ğ‘›ğ‘–\forall j\in[1,n]\setminus\{i\}âˆ€ italic_j âˆˆ [ 1 , italic_n ] âˆ– { italic_i }: Vâ¢aâ¢râ¢(si)âˆ©Vâ¢aâ¢râ¢(sj)=âˆ…ğ‘‰ğ‘ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘–ğ‘‰ğ‘ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘—Var(s_{i})\cap Var(s_{j})=\varnothingitalic_V italic_a italic_r ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) âˆ© italic_V italic_a italic_r ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = âˆ…,

  • â€¢

    (DN2) âˆ€âŸ¨iâ†¦uiâŸ©âˆˆÏ„+â¢(p)for-alldelimited-âŸ¨âŸ©maps-toğ‘–subscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–superscriptğœğ‘\forall\langle i\mapsto u_{i}\rangle\in\tau^{+}(p)âˆ€ âŸ¨ italic_i â†¦ italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ© âˆˆ italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_p ): sisubscriptğ‘ ğ‘–s_{i}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is more general than uisubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–u_{i}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT,

  • â€¢

    (DN3) âˆ€iâˆˆDâ¢oâ¢mâ¢(Ï„+â¢(p))for-allğ‘–ğ·ğ‘œğ‘šsuperscriptğœğ‘\forall i\in Dom(\tau^{+}(p))âˆ€ italic_i âˆˆ italic_D italic_o italic_m ( italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_p ) ), âˆ€qâ¢(t1,â€¦,tm)âˆˆğfor-allğ‘subscriptğ‘¡1â€¦subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘šğ\forall q(t_{1},\dots,t_{m})\in\textup{\bf B}âˆ€ italic_q ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) âˆˆ B, âˆ€jâˆ‰Dâ¢oâ¢mâ¢(Ï„+â¢(q))for-allğ‘—ğ·ğ‘œğ‘šsuperscriptğœğ‘\forall j\not\in Dom(\tau^{+}(q))âˆ€ italic_j âˆ‰ italic_D italic_o italic_m ( italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) ): Vâ¢aâ¢râ¢(si)âˆ©Vâ¢aâ¢râ¢(tj)=âˆ…,ğ‘‰ğ‘ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘–ğ‘‰ğ‘ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘—Var(s_{i})\cap Var(t_{j})=\varnothing,italic_V italic_a italic_r ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) âˆ© italic_V italic_a italic_r ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = âˆ… ,

  • â€¢

    (DN4) âˆ€qâ¢(t1,â€¦,tm)âˆˆğfor-allğ‘subscriptğ‘¡1â€¦subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘šğ\forall q(t_{1},\dots,t_{m})\in\textup{\bf B}âˆ€ italic_q ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) âˆˆ B, âˆ€âŸ¨jâ†¦ujâŸ©âˆˆÏ„+â¢(q)for-alldelimited-âŸ¨âŸ©maps-toğ‘—subscriptğ‘¢ğ‘—superscriptğœğ‘\forall\langle j\mapsto u_{j}\rangle\in\tau^{+}(q)âˆ€ âŸ¨ italic_j â†¦ italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ© âˆˆ italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ): tjsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘—t_{j}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is an instance of ujsubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘—u_{j}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

A set of positions with associated terms is DN for a program Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P if it is DN for each clause of Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P.

This definition says that any sisubscriptğ‘ ğ‘–s_{i}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT where iğ‘–iitalic_i is in the domain of Ï„+â¢(p)superscriptğœğ‘\tau^{+}(p)italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_p ) (i.e. position iğ‘–iitalic_i is distinguished by Ï„+superscriptğœ\tau^{+}italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT): (DN1) does not share its variables with the other arguments of the head, (DN2) is more general than the term uisubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–u_{i}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT that iğ‘–iitalic_i is mapped to by Ï„+â¢(p)superscriptğœğ‘\tau^{+}(p)italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_p ), (DN3) distributes its variables to some arguments tjsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘—t_{j}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of some atoms qâ¢(t1,â€¦,tm)ğ‘subscriptğ‘¡1â€¦subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘šq(t_{1},\dots,t_{m})italic_q ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) in B such that jğ‘—jitalic_j is in the domain of Ï„+â¢(q)superscriptğœğ‘\tau^{+}(q)italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) (i.e. position jğ‘—jitalic_j is distinguished by Ï„+superscriptğœ\tau^{+}italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT). Moreover, (DN4) says that any argument tjsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘—t_{j}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, where jğ‘—jitalic_j is distinguished by Ï„+superscriptğœ\tau^{+}italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, of any atom qâ¢(t1,â€¦,tm)ğ‘subscriptğ‘¡1â€¦subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘šq(t_{1},\dots,t_{m})italic_q ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) in B is such that tjsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘—t_{j}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is an instance of the term ujsubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘—u_{j}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT that jğ‘—jitalic_j is mapped to by Ï„+â¢(q)superscriptğœğ‘\tau^{+}(q)italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ).

Example 13 (ExampleÂ 11 continued)

Ï„+superscriptğœ\tau^{+}italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is DN for the following program:

    p(f(x),y) :- q(x,g(x)), p(x,g(y))
    q(a,g(x)) :- q(a,g(b))

The preceding notion is closed under renaming:

Proposition 3

Let cğ‘citalic_c be a clause and Ï„+superscriptğœ\tau^{+}italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be a set of positions with associated terms that is DN for cğ‘citalic_c. Then Ï„+superscriptğœ\tau^{+}italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is DN for every variant of cğ‘citalic_c.

Proof

The proof of this proposition is given in Appendix 1. âˆ

Notice that a set of positions is a particular set of positions with associated terms in the following sense.

Proposition 4

Let Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„ be a set of positions and xğ‘¥xitalic_x be any variable. Let Ï„+superscriptğœ\tau^{+}italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be the set of positions with associated terms defined as: for each pâˆˆÎ ğ‘normal-Î p\in\Piitalic_p âˆˆ roman_Î , Ï„+â¢(p):=(Ï„â¢(p)â†£{x})assignsuperscriptğœğ‘normal-â†£ğœğ‘ğ‘¥\tau^{+}(p):=(\;\tau(p)\rightarrowtail\{x\}\;)italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_p ) := ( italic_Ï„ ( italic_p ) â†£ { italic_x } ). Then, the following holds.

  1. 1.

    An atom Ağ´Aitalic_A is Î”â¢[Ï„]Î”delimited-[]ğœ\Delta[\tau]roman_Î” [ italic_Ï„ ]-more general than an atom BğµBitalic_B iff Ağ´Aitalic_A is Î”â¢[Ï„+]Î”delimited-[]superscriptğœ\Delta[\tau^{+}]roman_Î” [ italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ]-more general than BğµBitalic_B.

  2. 2.

    For any clause cğ‘citalic_c, Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„ is DN for cğ‘citalic_c iff Ï„+superscriptğœ\tau^{+}italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is DN for cğ‘citalic_c.

Proof

The proof follows from these remarks.

  • â€¢

    ItemÂ 1 is a direct consequence of the definition of â€œÎ”Î”\Deltaroman_Î”-more generalâ€ (see DefinitionÂ 3) and the definition of the filter associated to a set of positions (see DefinitionÂ 9) and to a set of positions with associated terms (see DefinitionÂ 12).

  • â€¢

    ItemÂ 2 is a direct consequence of the definition of DN sets of positions (see DefinitionÂ 10), and DN sets of positions with associated terms (see DefinitionÂ 13). âˆ

Finally, the sets of positions with associated terms of DefinitionÂ 13 were named after â€œDNâ€ because of the following result.

Theorem 4.2

Let Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P be a logic program and Ï„+superscriptğœ\tau^{+}italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be a set of positions with associated terms that is DN for Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P. Then Î”â¢[Ï„+]normal-Î”delimited-[]superscriptğœ\Delta[\tau^{+}]roman_Î” [ italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] is DN for Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P.

Proof

The proof of this theorem is given in Appendix 2. âˆ

For each predicate symbol pğ‘pitalic_p, let Ï•psubscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘\phi_{p}italic_Ï• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be the function from [1,ğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘–ğ‘¡ğ‘¦â¢(p)]1ğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘–ğ‘¡ğ‘¦ğ‘[1,\mathit{arity}(p)][ 1 , italic_arity ( italic_p ) ] to Tâ¢Uâ„’ğ‘‡subscriptğ‘ˆâ„’TU_{\mathcal{L}}italic_T italic_U start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT whose domain is empty. As in the case of sets of positions, the set of DN sets of positions with associated terms of a logic program is not empty as stated by the following proposition.

Proposition 5

Let Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P be a logic program. Then Ï„0+:=âŸ¨pâ†¦Ï•p|pâˆˆÎ âŸ©assignsubscriptsuperscriptğœ0inner-productmaps-toğ‘subscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘ğ‘normal-Î \tau^{+}_{0}:=\langle p\mapsto\phi_{p}\;|\;p\in\Pi\rangleitalic_Ï„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := âŸ¨ italic_p â†¦ italic_Ï• start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_p âˆˆ roman_Î  âŸ© is DN for Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P.

Proof

By DefinitionÂ 13. âˆ

Moreover, an atom Ağ´Aitalic_A is Î”â¢[Ï„0+]Î”delimited-[]subscriptsuperscriptğœ0\Delta[\tau^{+}_{0}]roman_Î” [ italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ]-more general than an atom BğµBitalic_B iff Ağ´Aitalic_A is more general than BğµBitalic_B. So, in the context of the filter Î”â¢[Ï„0+]Î”delimited-[]subscriptsuperscriptğœ0\Delta[\tau^{+}_{0}]roman_Î” [ italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ], the Î”Î”\Deltaroman_Î”-Lifting TheoremÂ 3.1 is the same as the Lifting TheoremÂ 1.1.

5 Examples

In this section, we focus on left derivations i.e. we only consider the leftmost selection rule: Qâ¢âŸ¹Qâ€²ğ‘„âŸ¹superscriptğ‘„â€²Q\mathop{\Longrightarrow}\limits Q^{\prime}italic_Q âŸ¹ italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a left derivation step if it is an SLD-derivation step whose selected atom is the first atom of Qğ‘„Qitalic_Q from the left. We say that a query Qğ‘„Qitalic_Q left loops w.r.t. a program Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P if there exists an infinite left derivation of Pâˆª{Q}ğ‘ƒğ‘„P\cup\{Q\}italic_P âˆª { italic_Q }. Notice that the Î”Î”\Deltaroman_Î”-Lifting TheoremÂ 3.1 provides a sufficient condition to identify left loops as it generates the following corollary.

Corollary 2 (from TheoremÂ 3.1)

Let Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P be a logic program and Î”normal-Î”\Deltaroman_Î” be a DN filter for Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P. If Aâ¢âŸ¹P*B1,ğ1ğ´subscriptsuperscriptnormal-âŸ¹ğ‘ƒsubscriptğµ1subscriptğ1A\mathop{\Longrightarrow}\limits^{*}_{P}B_{1},\textup{\bf B}_{1}italic_A âŸ¹ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and B1â¢âŸ¹P+B2,ğ2subscriptğµ1subscriptsuperscriptnormal-âŸ¹ğ‘ƒsubscriptğµ2subscriptğ2B_{1}\mathop{\Longrightarrow}\limits^{+}_{P}B_{2},\textup{\bf B}_{2}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ¹ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and B2subscriptğµ2B_{2}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is Î”normal-Î”\Deltaroman_Î”-more general than B1subscriptğµ1B_{1}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT then Pâˆª{A}ğ‘ƒğ´P\cup\{A\}italic_P âˆª { italic_A } left loops.

Proof

The proof is similar to that of CorollaryÂ 1.

This section presents some examples of atomic queries that have an infinite left derivation w.r.t. a given logic program. We use CorollaryÂ 2 with DN sets of positions and DN sets of positions with associated terms. In each case, it is not possible to conclude using the classical Lifting TheoremÂ 1.1. The last example exhibits a case where we are not able conclude.

Example 14

Let Î :={p}assignÎ ğ‘\Pi:=\{p\}roman_Î  := { italic_p } with pğ‘pitalic_p a relation symbol whose arity equals 2 and let

c:=pâ¢(fâ¢(x),y)â†pâ¢(x,gâ¢(y)).assignğ‘ğ‘ğ‘“ğ‘¥ğ‘¦â†ğ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘”ğ‘¦c:=p(f(x),y)\leftarrow p(x,g(y))\;.italic_c := italic_p ( italic_f ( italic_x ) , italic_y ) â† italic_p ( italic_x , italic_g ( italic_y ) ) .

Then

Ï„:=âŸ¨pâ†¦{2}âŸ©assignğœdelimited-âŸ¨âŸ©maps-toğ‘2\tau:=\langle p\mapsto\{2\}\rangleitalic_Ï„ := âŸ¨ italic_p â†¦ { 2 } âŸ©

is a DN set of positions for cğ‘citalic_c. The filter associated to Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„ (see DefinitionÂ 9) is

Î”â¢[Ï„]:=âŸ¨pâ†¦âŸ¨2â†¦fğ‘¡ğ‘Ÿğ‘¢ğ‘’âŸ©âŸ©.assignÎ”delimited-[]ğœdelimited-âŸ¨âŸ©maps-toğ‘delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©maps-to2subscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡ğ‘Ÿğ‘¢ğ‘’\Delta[\tau]:=\langle p\mapsto\langle 2\mapsto f_{\mathit{true}}\rangle\rangle\;.roman_Î” [ italic_Ï„ ] := âŸ¨ italic_p â†¦ âŸ¨ 2 â†¦ italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_true end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ© âŸ© .

Notice that, by TheoremÂ 4.1,

Î”â¢[Ï„]â¢Â is DN forÂ â¢{c}.Î”delimited-[]ğœÂ is DN forÂ ğ‘\Delta[\tau]\textrm{ is DN for }\{c\}\;.roman_Î” [ italic_Ï„ ] is DN for { italic_c } .

Moreover, from the head pâ¢(fâ¢(x),y)ğ‘ğ‘“ğ‘¥ğ‘¦p(f(x),y)italic_p ( italic_f ( italic_x ) , italic_y ) of cğ‘citalic_c we get

pâ¢(fâ¢(x),y)â¢âŸ¹cpâ¢(xâ€²,gâ¢(yâ€²)).ğ‘ğ‘“ğ‘¥ğ‘¦subscriptâŸ¹ğ‘ğ‘superscriptğ‘¥â€²ğ‘”superscriptğ‘¦â€²p(f(x),y)\mathop{\Longrightarrow}\limits_{c}p(x^{\prime},g(y^{\prime}))\;.italic_p ( italic_f ( italic_x ) , italic_y ) âŸ¹ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_g ( italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) .

Applying CorollaryÂ 2, as pâ¢(xâ€²,gâ¢(yâ€²))ğ‘superscriptğ‘¥â€²ğ‘”superscriptğ‘¦â€²p(x^{\prime},g(y^{\prime}))italic_p ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_g ( italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) is Î”â¢[Ï„]Î”delimited-[]ğœ\Delta[\tau]roman_Î” [ italic_Ï„ ]-more general than pâ¢(fâ¢(x),y)ğ‘ğ‘“ğ‘¥ğ‘¦p(f(x),y)italic_p ( italic_f ( italic_x ) , italic_y ), we get that

pâ¢(fâ¢(x),y)â¢Â left loops w.r.t.Â â¢{c}.ğ‘ğ‘“ğ‘¥ğ‘¦Â left loops w.r.t.Â ğ‘p(f(x),y)\textrm{ left loops w.r.t. }\{c\}\;.italic_p ( italic_f ( italic_x ) , italic_y ) left loops w.r.t. { italic_c } .

We point out that we do not get this result from the classical Lifting TheoremÂ 1.1 as pâ¢(xâ€²,gâ¢(yâ€²))ğ‘superscriptğ‘¥â€²ğ‘”superscriptğ‘¦â€²p(x^{\prime},g(y^{\prime}))italic_p ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_g ( italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) is not more general than pâ¢(fâ¢(x),y)ğ‘ğ‘“ğ‘¥ğ‘¦p(f(x),y)italic_p ( italic_f ( italic_x ) , italic_y ).

By the Î”Î”\Deltaroman_Î”-Lifting TheoremÂ 3.1, we can also conclude that each query that is Î”â¢[Ï„]Î”delimited-[]ğœ\Delta[\tau]roman_Î” [ italic_Ï„ ]-more general than pâ¢(fâ¢(x),y)ğ‘ğ‘“ğ‘¥ğ‘¦p(f(x),y)italic_p ( italic_f ( italic_x ) , italic_y ) also left loops w.r.t. {c}ğ‘\{c\}{ italic_c }. This means that each query of form pâ¢(t1,t2)ğ‘subscriptğ‘¡1subscriptğ‘¡2p(t_{1},t_{2})italic_p ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) where t1subscriptğ‘¡1t_{1}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a term that is more general than fâ¢(x)ğ‘“ğ‘¥f(x)italic_f ( italic_x ) and t2subscriptğ‘¡2t_{2}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is any term (because Ï„â¢(p)={2}ğœğ‘2\tau(p)=\{2\}italic_Ï„ ( italic_p ) = { 2 }) left loops w.r.t. {c}ğ‘\{c\}{ italic_c }. âˆ

Example 15

Let Î :={p}assignÎ ğ‘\Pi:=\{p\}roman_Î  := { italic_p } with pğ‘pitalic_p a relation symbol whose arity equals 2 and let

c:=pâ¢(fâ¢(x),gâ¢(y))â†pâ¢(x,gâ¢(hâ¢(y))).assignğ‘ğ‘ğ‘“ğ‘¥ğ‘”ğ‘¦â†ğ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘”â„ğ‘¦c:=p(f(x),g(y))\leftarrow p(x,g(h(y)))\;.italic_c := italic_p ( italic_f ( italic_x ) , italic_g ( italic_y ) ) â† italic_p ( italic_x , italic_g ( italic_h ( italic_y ) ) ) .

Notice that from the head pâ¢(fâ¢(x),gâ¢(y))ğ‘ğ‘“ğ‘¥ğ‘”ğ‘¦p(f(x),g(y))italic_p ( italic_f ( italic_x ) , italic_g ( italic_y ) ) of cğ‘citalic_c we get

pâ¢(fâ¢(x),gâ¢(y))â¢âŸ¹cpâ¢(xâ€²,gâ¢(hâ¢(yâ€²))).ğ‘ğ‘“ğ‘¥ğ‘”ğ‘¦subscriptâŸ¹ğ‘ğ‘superscriptğ‘¥â€²ğ‘”â„superscriptğ‘¦â€²p(f(x),g(y))\mathop{\Longrightarrow}\limits_{c}p(x^{\prime},g(h(y^{\prime})))\;.italic_p ( italic_f ( italic_x ) , italic_g ( italic_y ) ) âŸ¹ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_g ( italic_h ( italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) ) .

The only DN set of positions for cğ‘citalic_c is Ï„0:=âŸ¨pâ†¦âˆ…âŸ©assignsubscriptğœ0delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©maps-toğ‘\tau_{0}:=\langle p\mapsto\varnothing\rangleitalic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := âŸ¨ italic_p â†¦ âˆ… âŸ© because each argument of the head of cğ‘citalic_c is not a variable (see DefinitionÂ 10). Hence, as pâ¢(xâ€²,gâ¢(hâ¢(yâ€²)))ğ‘superscriptğ‘¥â€²ğ‘”â„superscriptğ‘¦â€²p(x^{\prime},g(h(y^{\prime})))italic_p ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_g ( italic_h ( italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) ) is not Î”â¢[Ï„0]Î”delimited-[]subscriptğœ0\Delta[\tau_{0}]roman_Î” [ italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ]-more general than pâ¢(fâ¢(x),gâ¢(y))ğ‘ğ‘“ğ‘¥ğ‘”ğ‘¦p(f(x),g(y))italic_p ( italic_f ( italic_x ) , italic_g ( italic_y ) ), we can not conclude using Ï„0subscriptğœ0\tau_{0}italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT that pâ¢(fâ¢(x),gâ¢(y))ğ‘ğ‘“ğ‘¥ğ‘”ğ‘¦p(f(x),g(y))italic_p ( italic_f ( italic_x ) , italic_g ( italic_y ) ) left loops w.r.t. {c}ğ‘\{c\}{ italic_c }.

However,

Ï„+:=âŸ¨pâ†¦âŸ¨2â†¦gâ¢(y)âŸ©âŸ©assignsuperscriptğœdelimited-âŸ¨âŸ©maps-toğ‘delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©maps-to2ğ‘”ğ‘¦\tau^{+}:=\langle\;p\mapsto\langle 2\mapsto g(y)\rangle\;\rangleitalic_Ï„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT := âŸ¨ italic_p â†¦ âŸ¨ 2 â†¦ italic_g ( italic_y ) âŸ© âŸ©

is a set of positions with associated terms that is DN for {c}ğ‘\{c\}{ italic_c }. Hence, by TheoremÂ 4.2, the associated filter Î”â¢[Ï„+]Î”delimited-[]superscriptğœ\Delta[\tau^{+}]roman_Î” [ italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] (see DefinitionÂ 12) is DN for {c}ğ‘\{c\}{ italic_c }. As pâ¢(xâ€²,gâ¢(hâ¢(yâ€²)))ğ‘superscriptğ‘¥â€²ğ‘”â„superscriptğ‘¦â€²p(x^{\prime},g(h(y^{\prime})))italic_p ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_g ( italic_h ( italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) ) is Î”â¢[Ï„+]Î”delimited-[]superscriptğœ\Delta[\tau^{+}]roman_Î” [ italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ]-more general than pâ¢(fâ¢(x),gâ¢(y))ğ‘ğ‘“ğ‘¥ğ‘”ğ‘¦p(f(x),g(y))italic_p ( italic_f ( italic_x ) , italic_g ( italic_y ) ), by CorollaryÂ 2 we get that

pâ¢(fâ¢(x),gâ¢(y))â¢Â left loops w.r.t.Â â¢{c}.ğ‘ğ‘“ğ‘¥ğ‘”ğ‘¦Â left loops w.r.t.Â ğ‘p(f(x),g(y))\textrm{ left loops w.r.t. }\{c\}\;.italic_p ( italic_f ( italic_x ) , italic_g ( italic_y ) ) left loops w.r.t. { italic_c } .

By the Î”Î”\Deltaroman_Î”-Lifting TheoremÂ 3.1, we can also conclude that each query that is Î”â¢[Ï„+]Î”delimited-[]superscriptğœ\Delta[\tau^{+}]roman_Î” [ italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ]-more general than pâ¢(fâ¢(x),gâ¢(y))ğ‘ğ‘“ğ‘¥ğ‘”ğ‘¦p(f(x),g(y))italic_p ( italic_f ( italic_x ) , italic_g ( italic_y ) ) also left loops w.r.t. {c}ğ‘\{c\}{ italic_c }. This means that each query of form pâ¢(t1,t2)ğ‘subscriptğ‘¡1subscriptğ‘¡2p(t_{1},t_{2})italic_p ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) where t1subscriptğ‘¡1t_{1}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a term that is more general than fâ¢(x)ğ‘“ğ‘¥f(x)italic_f ( italic_x ) and t2subscriptğ‘¡2t_{2}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is any instance of gâ¢(y)ğ‘”ğ‘¦g(y)italic_g ( italic_y ) (because Ï„+â¢(p)=âŸ¨2â†¦gâ¢(y)âŸ©superscriptğœğ‘delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©maps-to2ğ‘”ğ‘¦\tau^{+}(p)=\langle 2\mapsto g(y)\rangleitalic_Ï„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_p ) = âŸ¨ 2 â†¦ italic_g ( italic_y ) âŸ©) left loops w.r.t. {c}ğ‘\{c\}{ italic_c }. âˆ

Example 16

Let Î :={p,q}assignÎ ğ‘ğ‘\Pi:=\{p,q\}roman_Î  := { italic_p , italic_q } with pğ‘pitalic_p and qğ‘qitalic_q two relation symbols whose arity equals 2. Let

c1:=pâ¢(fâ¢(x),y)â†qâ¢(x,gâ¢(x)),pâ¢(x,gâ¢(y))c2:=qâ¢(a,gâ¢(x))â†qâ¢(a,gâ¢(b))assignsubscriptğ‘1absentâ†ğ‘ğ‘“ğ‘¥ğ‘¦absentğ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘”ğ‘¥ğ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘”ğ‘¦assignsubscriptğ‘2absentâ†ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘”ğ‘¥absentğ‘ğ‘ğ‘”ğ‘\begin{array}[]{r@{\;:=\;}r@{\;\leftarrow\;}l}c_{1}&p(f(x),y)&q(x,g(x)),\;p(x,g(y))\\[4.30554pt] c_{2}&q(a,g(x))&q(a,g(b))\end{array}start_ARRAY start_ROW start_CELL italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := end_CELL start_CELL italic_p ( italic_f ( italic_x ) , italic_y ) â† end_CELL start_CELL italic_q ( italic_x , italic_g ( italic_x ) ) , italic_p ( italic_x , italic_g ( italic_y ) ) end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := end_CELL start_CELL italic_q ( italic_a , italic_g ( italic_x ) ) â† end_CELL start_CELL italic_q ( italic_a , italic_g ( italic_b ) ) end_CELL end_ROW end_ARRAY

Then

Ï„+:=âŸ¨pâ†¦âŸ¨2â†¦yâŸ©,qâ†¦âŸ¨2â†¦gâ¢(x)âŸ©âŸ©assignsuperscriptğœdelimited-âŸ¨âŸ©formulae-sequencemaps-toğ‘delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©maps-to2ğ‘¦maps-toğ‘delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©maps-to2ğ‘”ğ‘¥\tau^{+}:=\langle\;p\mapsto\langle 2\mapsto y\rangle,\;\;q\mapsto\langle 2\mapsto g(x)\rangle\;\rangleitalic_Ï„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT := âŸ¨ italic_p â†¦ âŸ¨ 2 â†¦ italic_y âŸ© , italic_q â†¦ âŸ¨ 2 â†¦ italic_g ( italic_x ) âŸ© âŸ©

is a set of positions with associated terms that is DN for {c1,c2}subscriptğ‘1subscriptğ‘2\{c_{1},c_{2}\}{ italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT }. Hence, by TheoremÂ 4.2, the associated filter Î”â¢[Ï„+]Î”delimited-[]superscriptğœ\Delta[\tau^{+}]roman_Î” [ italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] (see DefinitionÂ 12) is DN for {c1,c2}subscriptğ‘1subscriptğ‘2\{c_{1},c_{2}\}{ italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT }. Moreover, from the head qâ¢(a,gâ¢(x))ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘”ğ‘¥q(a,g(x))italic_q ( italic_a , italic_g ( italic_x ) ) of c2subscriptğ‘2c_{2}italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT we get

qâ¢(a,gâ¢(x))â¢âŸ¹c2qâ¢(a,gâ¢(b)).ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘”ğ‘¥subscriptâŸ¹subscriptğ‘2ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘”ğ‘q(a,g(x))\mathop{\Longrightarrow}\limits_{c_{2}}q(a,g(b))\;.italic_q ( italic_a , italic_g ( italic_x ) ) âŸ¹ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q ( italic_a , italic_g ( italic_b ) ) .

Applying CorollaryÂ 2, as qâ¢(a,gâ¢(b))ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘”ğ‘q(a,g(b))italic_q ( italic_a , italic_g ( italic_b ) ) is Î”â¢[Ï„+]Î”delimited-[]superscriptğœ\Delta[\tau^{+}]roman_Î” [ italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ]-more general than qâ¢(a,gâ¢(x))ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘”ğ‘¥q(a,g(x))italic_q ( italic_a , italic_g ( italic_x ) ), we get that

By the Î”Î”\Deltaroman_Î”-Lifting TheoremÂ 3.1, each query of form qâ¢(t1,t2)ğ‘subscriptğ‘¡1subscriptğ‘¡2q(t_{1},t_{2})italic_q ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) where t1subscriptğ‘¡1t_{1}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a term that is more general than ağ‘aitalic_a and t2subscriptğ‘¡2t_{2}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is any instance of gâ¢(x)ğ‘”ğ‘¥g(x)italic_g ( italic_x ) (because Ï„+â¢(q)=âŸ¨2â†¦gâ¢(x)âŸ©superscriptğœğ‘delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©maps-to2ğ‘”ğ‘¥\tau^{+}(q)=\langle 2\mapsto g(x)\rangleitalic_Ï„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) = âŸ¨ 2 â†¦ italic_g ( italic_x ) âŸ©) left loops w.r.t. c2subscriptğ‘2c_{2}italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Notice that from the head pâ¢(fâ¢(x),y)ğ‘ğ‘“ğ‘¥ğ‘¦p(f(x),y)italic_p ( italic_f ( italic_x ) , italic_y ) of c1subscriptğ‘1c_{1}italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT we get

pâ¢(fâ¢(x),y)â¢âŸ¹c1qâ¢(xâ€²,gâ¢(xâ€²)),pâ¢(xâ€²,gâ¢(yâ€²)).ğ‘ğ‘“ğ‘¥ğ‘¦subscriptâŸ¹subscriptğ‘1ğ‘superscriptğ‘¥â€²ğ‘”superscriptğ‘¥â€²ğ‘superscriptğ‘¥â€²ğ‘”superscriptğ‘¦â€²p(f(x),y)\mathop{\Longrightarrow}\limits_{c_{1}}q(x^{\prime},g(x^{\prime})),p(x^{\prime},g(y^{\prime}))\;.italic_p ( italic_f ( italic_x ) , italic_y ) âŸ¹ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_g ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) , italic_p ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_g ( italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) .

As qâ¢(xâ€²,gâ¢(xâ€²))ğ‘superscriptğ‘¥â€²ğ‘”superscriptğ‘¥â€²q(x^{\prime},g(x^{\prime}))italic_q ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_g ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) is such that xâ€²superscriptğ‘¥â€²x^{\prime}italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is more general than ağ‘aitalic_a and gâ¢(xâ€²)ğ‘”superscriptğ‘¥â€²g(x^{\prime})italic_g ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) is an instance of gâ¢(x)ğ‘”ğ‘¥g(x)italic_g ( italic_x ), we get that qâ¢(xâ€²,gâ¢(xâ€²))ğ‘superscriptğ‘¥â€²ğ‘”superscriptğ‘¥â€²q(x^{\prime},g(x^{\prime}))italic_q ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_g ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) left loops w.r.t. c2subscriptğ‘2c_{2}italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Consequently, pâ¢(fâ¢(x),y)ğ‘ğ‘“ğ‘¥ğ‘¦p(f(x),y)italic_p ( italic_f ( italic_x ) , italic_y ) left loops w.r.t. {c1,c2}subscriptğ‘1subscriptğ‘2\{c_{1},c_{2}\}{ italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT }. So, again by the Î”Î”\Deltaroman_Î”-Lifting TheoremÂ 3.1, each query of form pâ¢(t1,t2)ğ‘subscriptğ‘¡1subscriptğ‘¡2p(t_{1},t_{2})italic_p ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), where t1subscriptğ‘¡1t_{1}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a term that is more general than fâ¢(x)ğ‘“ğ‘¥f(x)italic_f ( italic_x ) and t2subscriptğ‘¡2t_{2}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is any instance of yğ‘¦yitalic_y (because Ï„+â¢(p)=âŸ¨2â†¦yâŸ©superscriptğœğ‘delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©maps-to2ğ‘¦\tau^{+}(p)=\langle 2\mapsto y\rangleitalic_Ï„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_p ) = âŸ¨ 2 â†¦ italic_y âŸ©) left loops w.r.t. {c1,c2}subscriptğ‘1subscriptğ‘2\{c_{1},c_{2}\}{ italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT }. âˆ

Example 17

Let Î :={p}assignÎ ğ‘\Pi:=\{p\}roman_Î  := { italic_p } with pğ‘pitalic_p a relation symbol whose arity equals 2 and let

c:=pâ¢(x,x)â†pâ¢(fâ¢(x),fâ¢(x)).assignğ‘ğ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘¥â†ğ‘ğ‘“ğ‘¥ğ‘“ğ‘¥c:=p(x,x)\leftarrow p(f(x),f(x))\;.italic_c := italic_p ( italic_x , italic_x ) â† italic_p ( italic_f ( italic_x ) , italic_f ( italic_x ) ) .

As the arguments of the head of cğ‘citalic_c have one common variable xğ‘¥xitalic_x, the only set of positions with associated terms that is DN for cğ‘citalic_c is Ï„0+subscriptsuperscriptğœ0\tau^{+}_{0}italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT such that the domain of Ï„0+â¢(p)subscriptsuperscriptğœ0ğ‘\tau^{+}_{0}(p)italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_p ) is empty (see (DN1) in DefinitionÂ 13). Notice that from the head pâ¢(x,x)ğ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘¥p(x,x)italic_p ( italic_x , italic_x ) of cğ‘citalic_c we get

pâ¢(x,x)â¢âŸ¹cpâ¢(fâ¢(x1),fâ¢(x1))â¢â‹¯â‹¯â¢pâ¢(fnâ¢(xn),fnâ¢(xn))â¢âŸ¹cpâ¢(fn+1â¢(xn+1),fn+1â¢(xn+1))â¢â‹¯ğ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘¥subscriptâŸ¹ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘“subscriptğ‘¥1ğ‘“subscriptğ‘¥1â‹¯â‹¯ğ‘superscriptğ‘“ğ‘›subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›superscriptğ‘“ğ‘›subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›subscriptâŸ¹ğ‘ğ‘superscriptğ‘“ğ‘›1subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›1superscriptğ‘“ğ‘›1subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›1â‹¯\begin{array}[]{l}p(x,x)\mathop{\Longrightarrow}\limits_{c}p(f(x_{1}),f(x_{1}))\cdots\\[4.30554pt] \hskip 42.67912pt\cdots p(f^{n}(x_{n}),f^{n}(x_{n}))\mathop{\Longrightarrow}\limits_{c}p(f^{n+1}(x_{n+1}),f^{n+1}(x_{n+1}))\cdots\end{array}start_ARRAY start_ROW start_CELL italic_p ( italic_x , italic_x ) âŸ¹ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( italic_f ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , italic_f ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) â‹¯ end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL â‹¯ italic_p ( italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) âŸ¹ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) â‹¯ end_CELL end_ROW end_ARRAY

As the arguments of pğ‘pitalic_p grow from step to step, there cannot be any query in the derivation that is Î”â¢[Ï„0+]Î”delimited-[]subscriptsuperscriptğœ0\Delta[\tau^{+}_{0}]roman_Î” [ italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ]-more general than one of its ancestors. Consequently, we can not conclude that pâ¢(x,x)ğ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘¥p(x,x)italic_p ( italic_x , italic_x ) left loops w.r.t cğ‘citalic_c. âˆ

6 Related Works

Some extensions of the Lifting Theorem with respect to infinite derivations are presented in [9], where the authors study numerous properties of finite failure. The non-ground finite failure set of a logic program is defined as the set of possibly non-ground atoms which admit a fair finitely failed SLD-tree w.r.t. the program. This denotation is shown correct in the following sense. If two programs have the same non-ground finite failure set, then any ground or non-ground goal which finitely fails w.r.t. one program also finitely fails w.r.t. the other. Such a property is false when we consider the standard ground finite failure set. The proof of correctness of the non-ground finite failure semantics relies on the following result. First, a derivation is called non-perpetual if it is a fair infinite derivation and there exists a finite depth from which unfolding does not instantiate the original goal any more. Then the authors define the definite answer goal of a non-perpetual derivation as the maximal instantiation of the original goal. A crucial lemma states that any instance of the definite answer goal admits a similar non-perpetual derivation. Compared to our work, note that we do need fairness as an hypothesis for the Î”Î”\Deltaroman_Î”-Lifting TheoremÂ 3.1. On the other hand, investigating the relationships between non-ground arguments of definite answer and neutral arguments is an interesting problem.

Loop checking in logic programming is also a subject related to our work. In this area, [4] sets up some solid foundations. A loop check is a device to prune derivations when it seems appropriate. A loop checker is defined as sound if no solution is lost. It is complete if all infinite derivations are pruned. A complete loop check may also prune finite derivations. The authors shows that even for function-free programs (also known as Datalog programs), sound and complete loop checks are out of reach. Completeness is shown only for some restricted classes of function-free programs.

We now review loop checking in more details. To our best knowledge, among all existing loop checking mechanisms only OS-check [17], EVA-check [19] and VAF-check [20] are suitable for logic programs with function symbols. They rely on a structural characteristic of infinite SLD-derivations, namely, the growth of the size of some generated subgoals. This is what the following theorem states.

Theorem 6.1

Consider an infinite SLD-derivation Î¾ğœ‰\xiitalic_Î¾ where the leftmost selection rule is used. Then there are infinitely many queries Qi1subscriptğ‘„subscriptğ‘–1Q_{i_{1}}italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, Qi2subscriptğ‘„subscriptğ‘–2Q_{i_{2}}italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, â€¦ (with i1<i2<â€¦subscriptğ‘–1subscriptğ‘–2italic-â€¦i_{1}<i_{2}<\dotsitalic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < italic_â€¦) in Î¾ğœ‰\xiitalic_Î¾ such that for any jâ‰¥1ğ‘—1j\geq 1italic_j â‰¥ 1, the selected atom Aijsubscriptğ´subscriptğ‘–ğ‘—A_{i_{j}}italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of Qijsubscriptğ‘„subscriptğ‘–ğ‘—Q_{i_{j}}italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is an ancestor of the selected atom Aij+1subscriptğ´subscriptğ‘–ğ‘—1A_{i_{j+1}}italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of Qij+1subscriptğ‘„subscriptğ‘–ğ‘—1Q_{i_{j+1}}italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ğ‘ ğ‘–ğ‘§ğ‘’â¢(Aij+1)â‰¥ğ‘ ğ‘–ğ‘§ğ‘’â¢(Aij)ğ‘ ğ‘–ğ‘§ğ‘’subscriptğ´subscriptğ‘–ğ‘—1ğ‘ ğ‘–ğ‘§ğ‘’subscriptğ´subscriptğ‘–ğ‘—\mathit{size}(A_{i_{j+1}})\geq\mathit{size}(A_{i_{j}})italic_size ( italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) â‰¥ italic_size ( italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ).

Here, ğ‘ ğ‘–ğ‘§ğ‘’ğ‘ ğ‘–ğ‘§ğ‘’\mathit{size}italic_size is a given function that maps an atom to its size which is defined in terms of the number of symbols appearing in the atom. As this theorem does not provide any sufficient condition to detect infinite SLD-derivations, the three loop checking mechanisms mentioned above may detect finite derivations as infinite. However, these mechanisms are complete w.r.t. the leftmost selection rule i.e. they detect all infinite loops when the leftmost selection rule is used.

OS-check (for OverSize loop check) was first introduced by Shalin [17, 18] and was then formalized by Bol [3]. It is based on a function ğ‘ ğ‘–ğ‘§ğ‘’ğ‘ ğ‘–ğ‘§ğ‘’\mathit{size}italic_size that can have one of the three following definitions: for any atoms Ağ´Aitalic_A and BğµBitalic_B, either ğ‘ ğ‘–ğ‘§ğ‘’â¢(A)=ğ‘ ğ‘–ğ‘§ğ‘’â¢(B)ğ‘ ğ‘–ğ‘§ğ‘’ğ´ğ‘ ğ‘–ğ‘§ğ‘’ğµ\mathit{size}(A)=\mathit{size}(B)italic_size ( italic_A ) = italic_size ( italic_B ), either ğ‘ ğ‘–ğ‘§ğ‘’â¢(A)ğ‘ ğ‘–ğ‘§ğ‘’ğ´\mathit{size}(A)italic_size ( italic_A ) (resp. ğ‘ ğ‘–ğ‘§ğ‘’â¢(B)ğ‘ ğ‘–ğ‘§ğ‘’ğµ\mathit{size}(B)italic_size ( italic_B )) is the count of symbols appearing in Ağ´Aitalic_A (resp. BğµBitalic_B), either ğ‘ ğ‘–ğ‘§ğ‘’â¢(A)â‰¤ğ‘ ğ‘–ğ‘§ğ‘’â¢(B)ğ‘ ğ‘–ğ‘§ğ‘’ğ´ğ‘ ğ‘–ğ‘§ğ‘’ğµ\mathit{size}(A)\leq\mathit{size}(B)italic_size ( italic_A ) â‰¤ italic_size ( italic_B ) if for each iğ‘–iitalic_i, the count of symbols of the iğ‘–iitalic_i-th argument of Ağ´Aitalic_A is smaller than or equal to that of the iğ‘–iitalic_i-th argument of BğµBitalic_B. OS-check says that an SLD-derivation may be infinite if it generates an atomic subgoal Ağ´Aitalic_A that is oversized, i.e. that has ancestor subgoals which have the same predicate symbol as Ağ´Aitalic_A and whose size is smaller than or equal to that of Ağ´Aitalic_A.

EVA-check (for Extented Variant Atoms loop check) was introduced by Shen [19]. It is based on the notion of generalized variants. EVA-check says that an SLD-derivation may be infinite if it generates an atomic subgoal Ağ´Aitalic_A that is a generalized variant of some of its ancestor Aâ€²superscriptğ´â€²A^{\prime}italic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, i.e. Ağ´Aitalic_A is a variant of Aâ€²superscriptğ´â€²A^{\prime}italic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT except for some arguments whose size increases from Aâ€²superscriptğ´â€²A^{\prime}italic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to Ağ´Aitalic_A via a set of recursive clauses. Here the size function that is used applies to predicate arguments, i.e. to terms, and it is fixed: it is defined as the the count of symbols that appear in the terms. EVA-check is more reliable than OS-check because it is less likely to mis-identify infinite loops [19]. This is mainly due to the fact that, unlike OS-check, EVA-check refers to the informative internal structure of subgoals.

VAF-check (for Variant Atoms loop check for logic programs with Functions) was proposed by Shen et al. [20]. It is based on the notion of expanded variants. VAF-check says that an SLD-derivation may be infinite if it generates an atomic subgoal Ağ´Aitalic_A that is an expanded variant of some of its ancestor Aâ€²superscriptğ´â€²A^{\prime}italic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, i.e. Ağ´Aitalic_A is a variant of Aâ€²superscriptğ´â€²A^{\prime}italic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT except for some arguments ti1,â€¦,tinsubscriptğ‘¡subscriptğ‘–1â€¦subscriptğ‘¡subscriptğ‘–ğ‘›t_{i_{1}},\dots,t_{i_{n}}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT such that: ti1subscriptğ‘¡subscriptğ‘–1t_{i_{1}}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT grows from Aâ€²superscriptğ´â€²A^{\prime}italic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to Ağ´Aitalic_A into a function containing ti1subscriptğ‘¡subscriptğ‘–1t_{i_{1}}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, â€¦, tinsubscriptğ‘¡subscriptğ‘–ğ‘›t_{i_{n}}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT grows from Aâ€²superscriptğ´â€²A^{\prime}italic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to Ağ´Aitalic_A into a function containing tinsubscriptğ‘¡subscriptğ‘–ğ‘›t_{i_{n}}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. VAF-check is as reliable as and more efficient than EVA-check [20].

The main difference with our work is that we want to pinpoint some infinite derivations, based on syntactical properties of the program. We are not interested in completeness nor in soundness. Notice, however, that using the Î”Î”\Deltaroman_Î”-Lifting TheoremÂ 3.1 as a loop checker leads to a device that is neither complete (see ExampleÂ 17) nor sound since the Lifting TheoremÂ 1.1 is a particular case of the Î”Î”\Deltaroman_Î”-Lifting TheoremÂ 3.1.

7 Conclusion

We have presented a generalization of the lifting lemma for logic programming, which allows to disregard some arguments, termed neutral arguments, while checking for subsumption. We have investigated the model theoretic consequence of this generalization and have proposed two syntactic criteria for statically identifying neutral arguments.

A first application of this work has already been presented in [14], in the area of termination analysis of logic programs. We combine cTI [13], a termination inference tool with a non-termination inference analyzer whose correctness relies on our generalized lifting lemma. The resulting combined analysis may sometimes characterize the termination behavior of some concrete logic program w.r.t. to the left selection rule and the language we use to describe classes of queries.

Finally, this paper leaves numerous questions open. For instance, it might be interesting to try to generalize this approach to constraint logic programming [10]. Can we obtain higher level proofs compared to those we give? Can we propose more abstract or semantically-based criteria for identifying neutral arguments?

Acknowledgements. We thank Ulrich Neumerkel for initial discussions on this topic and Roberto Bagnara for interesting suggestions.

âˆ

8.2 Proof of PropositionÂ 3

Let c:=pâ¢(s1,â€¦,sn)â†ğassignğ‘ğ‘subscriptğ‘ 1â€¦subscriptğ‘ ğ‘›â†ğc:=p(s_{1},\dots,s_{n})\leftarrow\textup{\bf B}italic_c := italic_p ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) â† B and câ€²:=pâ¢(s1â€²,â€¦,snâ€²)â†ğâ€²assignsuperscriptğ‘â€²ğ‘subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ â€²1â€¦subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ â€²ğ‘›â†superscriptğâ€²c^{\prime}:=p(s^{\prime}_{1},\dots,s^{\prime}_{n})\leftarrow\textup{\bf B}^{\prime}italic_c start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT := italic_p ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) â† B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be a variant of cğ‘citalic_c. (DN1)

Let iâˆˆDâ¢oâ¢mâ¢(Ï„+â¢(p))ğ‘–ğ·ğ‘œğ‘šsuperscriptğœğ‘i\in Dom(\tau^{+}(p))italic_i âˆˆ italic_D italic_o italic_m ( italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_p ) ). Suppose that there exists jâ‰ iğ‘—ğ‘–j\neq iitalic_j â‰  italic_i such that Vâ¢aâ¢râ¢(siâ€²)âˆ©Vâ¢aâ¢râ¢(sjâ€²)â‰ âˆ…ğ‘‰ğ‘ğ‘Ÿsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘ â€²ğ‘–ğ‘‰ğ‘ğ‘Ÿsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘ â€²ğ‘—Var(s^{\prime}_{i})\cap Var(s^{\prime}_{j})\neq\varnothingitalic_V italic_a italic_r ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) âˆ© italic_V italic_a italic_r ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) â‰  âˆ… and let us derive a contradiction.

Let xâ€²âˆˆVâ¢aâ¢râ¢(siâ€²)âˆ©Vâ¢aâ¢râ¢(sjâ€²)superscriptğ‘¥â€²ğ‘‰ğ‘ğ‘Ÿsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘ â€²ğ‘–ğ‘‰ğ‘ğ‘Ÿsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘ â€²ğ‘—x^{\prime}\in Var(s^{\prime}_{i})\cap Var(s^{\prime}_{j})italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ italic_V italic_a italic_r ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) âˆ© italic_V italic_a italic_r ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). As sjâ€²=sjâ¢Î³subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ â€²ğ‘—subscriptğ‘ ğ‘—ğ›¾s^{\prime}_{j}=s_{j}\gammaitalic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î³, there exists xâˆˆVâ¢aâ¢râ¢(sj)ğ‘¥ğ‘‰ğ‘ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘—x\in Var(s_{j})italic_x âˆˆ italic_V italic_a italic_r ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) such that xâ€²=xâ¢Î³superscriptğ‘¥â€²ğ‘¥ğ›¾x^{\prime}=x\gammaitalic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_x italic_Î³.

For such an xğ‘¥xitalic_x, as jâ‰ iğ‘—ğ‘–j\neq iitalic_j â‰  italic_i and as Vâ¢aâ¢râ¢(si)âˆ©Vâ¢aâ¢râ¢(sj)=âˆ…ğ‘‰ğ‘ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘–ğ‘‰ğ‘ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘—Var(s_{i})\cap Var(s_{j})=\varnothingitalic_V italic_a italic_r ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) âˆ© italic_V italic_a italic_r ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = âˆ… (because Ï„+superscriptğœ\tau^{+}italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is DN for cğ‘citalic_c), we have xâˆ‰Vâ¢aâ¢râ¢(si)ğ‘¥ğ‘‰ğ‘ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘–x\not\in Var(s_{i})italic_x âˆ‰ italic_V italic_a italic_r ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). So, as Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ is a 1-1 and onto mapping from its domain to itself, we have xâ¢Î³âˆ‰Vâ¢aâ¢râ¢(siâ¢Î³)ğ‘¥ğ›¾ğ‘‰ğ‘ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘–ğ›¾x\gamma\not\in Var(s_{i}\gamma)italic_x italic_Î³ âˆ‰ italic_V italic_a italic_r ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î³ )111 Because if xâ¢Î³âˆˆVâ¢aâ¢râ¢(siâ¢Î³)ğ‘¥ğ›¾ğ‘‰ğ‘ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘–ğ›¾x\gamma\in Var(s_{i}\gamma)italic_x italic_Î³ âˆˆ italic_V italic_a italic_r ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î³ ), then either xâˆˆVâ¢aâ¢râ¢(si)ğ‘¥ğ‘‰ğ‘ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘–x\in Var(s_{i})italic_x âˆˆ italic_V italic_a italic_r ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), either xâ¢Î³âˆˆVâ¢aâ¢râ¢(si)ğ‘¥ğ›¾ğ‘‰ğ‘ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘–x\gamma\in Var(s_{i})italic_x italic_Î³ âˆˆ italic_V italic_a italic_r ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) and (xâ¢Î³)â¢Î³=xâ¢Î³ğ‘¥ğ›¾ğ›¾ğ‘¥ğ›¾(x\gamma)\gamma=x\gamma( italic_x italic_Î³ ) italic_Î³ = italic_x italic_Î³. The former case is impossible because we said that xâˆ‰Vâ¢aâ¢râ¢(si)ğ‘¥ğ‘‰ğ‘ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘–x\not\in Var(s_{i})italic_x âˆ‰ italic_V italic_a italic_r ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). The latter case is impossible too because (xâ¢Î³)â¢Î³=xâ¢Î³ğ‘¥ğ›¾ğ›¾ğ‘¥ğ›¾(x\gamma)\gamma=x\gamma( italic_x italic_Î³ ) italic_Î³ = italic_x italic_Î³ implies that xâ¢Î³âˆ‰Dâ¢oâ¢mâ¢(Î³)ğ‘¥ğ›¾ğ·ğ‘œğ‘šğ›¾x\gamma\not\in Dom(\gamma)italic_x italic_Î³ âˆ‰ italic_D italic_o italic_m ( italic_Î³ ) i.e. xâˆ‰Dâ¢oâ¢mâ¢(Î³)ğ‘¥ğ·ğ‘œğ‘šğ›¾x\not\in Dom(\gamma)italic_x âˆ‰ italic_D italic_o italic_m ( italic_Î³ ) (because Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ is a 1-1 and onto mapping from its domain to itself); so, x=xâ¢Î³ğ‘¥ğ‘¥ğ›¾x=x\gammaitalic_x = italic_x italic_Î³ i.e., as xâ¢Î³âˆˆVâ¢aâ¢râ¢(si)ğ‘¥ğ›¾ğ‘‰ğ‘ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘–x\gamma\in Var(s_{i})italic_x italic_Î³ âˆˆ italic_V italic_a italic_r ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), xâˆˆVâ¢aâ¢râ¢(si)ğ‘¥ğ‘‰ğ‘ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘–x\in Var(s_{i})italic_x âˆˆ italic_V italic_a italic_r ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). , i.e. xâ€²âˆ‰Vâ¢aâ¢râ¢(siâ€²)superscriptğ‘¥â€²ğ‘‰ğ‘ğ‘Ÿsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘ â€²ğ‘–x^{\prime}\not\in Var(s^{\prime}_{i})italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ‰ italic_V italic_a italic_r ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). Contradiction!

Consequently, Vâ¢aâ¢râ¢(siâ€²)âˆ©Vâ¢aâ¢râ¢(sjâ€²)=âˆ…ğ‘‰ğ‘ğ‘Ÿsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘ â€²ğ‘–ğ‘‰ğ‘ğ‘Ÿsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘ â€²ğ‘—Var(s^{\prime}_{i})\cap Var(s^{\prime}_{j})=\varnothingitalic_V italic_a italic_r ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) âˆ© italic_V italic_a italic_r ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = âˆ….

(DN2)

Let âŸ¨iâ†¦uiâŸ©âˆˆÏ„+â¢(p)delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©maps-toğ‘–subscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–superscriptğœğ‘\langle i\mapsto u_{i}\rangle\in\tau^{+}(p)âŸ¨ italic_i â†¦ italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ© âˆˆ italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_p ). As sisubscriptğ‘ ğ‘–s_{i}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is more general than uisubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–u_{i}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (because Ï„+superscriptğœ\tau^{+}italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is DN for cğ‘citalic_c) and as siâ€²subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ â€²ğ‘–s^{\prime}_{i}italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a variant of sisubscriptğ‘ ğ‘–s_{i}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, siâ€²subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ â€²ğ‘–s^{\prime}_{i}italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is more general than uisubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–u_{i}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

(DN3)

Let iâˆˆDâ¢oâ¢mâ¢(Ï„+â¢(p))ğ‘–ğ·ğ‘œğ‘šsuperscriptğœğ‘i\in Dom(\tau^{+}(p))italic_i âˆˆ italic_D italic_o italic_m ( italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_p ) ). Suppose that there exists qâ¢(t1â€²,â€¦,tmâ€²)âˆˆğâ€²ğ‘subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¡â€²1â€¦subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¡â€²ğ‘šsuperscriptğâ€²q(t^{\prime}_{1},\dots,t^{\prime}_{m})\in\textup{\bf B}^{\prime}italic_q ( italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) âˆˆ B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and jâˆ‰Dâ¢oâ¢mâ¢(Ï„+â¢(q))ğ‘—ğ·ğ‘œğ‘šsuperscriptğœğ‘j\not\in Dom(\tau^{+}(q))italic_j âˆ‰ italic_D italic_o italic_m ( italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) ) such that Vâ¢aâ¢râ¢(siâ€²)âˆ©Vâ¢aâ¢râ¢(tjâ€²)â‰ âˆ…ğ‘‰ğ‘ğ‘Ÿsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘ â€²ğ‘–ğ‘‰ğ‘ğ‘Ÿsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘¡â€²ğ‘—Var(s^{\prime}_{i})\cap Var(t^{\prime}_{j})\neq\varnothingitalic_V italic_a italic_r ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) âˆ© italic_V italic_a italic_r ( italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) â‰  âˆ…. Let us derive a contradiction.

Let xâ€²âˆˆVâ¢aâ¢râ¢(siâ€²)âˆ©Vâ¢aâ¢râ¢(tjâ€²)superscriptğ‘¥â€²ğ‘‰ğ‘ğ‘Ÿsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘ â€²ğ‘–ğ‘‰ğ‘ğ‘Ÿsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘¡â€²ğ‘—x^{\prime}\in Var(s^{\prime}_{i})\cap Var(t^{\prime}_{j})italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ italic_V italic_a italic_r ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) âˆ© italic_V italic_a italic_r ( italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). As ğâ€²=ğâ¢Î³superscriptğâ€²ğğ›¾\textup{\bf B}^{\prime}=\textup{\bf B}\gammaB start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = B italic_Î³, there exists qâ¢(t1,â€¦,tm)âˆˆğğ‘subscriptğ‘¡1â€¦subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘šğq(t_{1},\dots,t_{m})\in\textup{\bf B}italic_q ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) âˆˆ B such that qâ¢(t1â€²,â€¦,tmâ€²)=qâ¢(t1,â€¦,tm)â¢Î³ğ‘subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¡â€²1â€¦subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¡â€²ğ‘šğ‘subscriptğ‘¡1â€¦subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘šğ›¾q(t^{\prime}_{1},\dots,t^{\prime}_{m})=q(t_{1},\dots,t_{m})\gammaitalic_q ( italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = italic_q ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_Î³, i.e. tjâ€²=tjâ¢Î³subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¡â€²ğ‘—subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘—ğ›¾t^{\prime}_{j}=t_{j}\gammaitalic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î³. So, as xâ€²âˆˆVâ¢aâ¢râ¢(tjâ€²)superscriptğ‘¥â€²ğ‘‰ğ‘ğ‘Ÿsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘¡â€²ğ‘—x^{\prime}\in Var(t^{\prime}_{j})italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ italic_V italic_a italic_r ( italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), there exists xâˆˆVâ¢aâ¢râ¢(tj)ğ‘¥ğ‘‰ğ‘ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘—x\in Var(t_{j})italic_x âˆˆ italic_V italic_a italic_r ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) such that xâ€²=xâ¢Î³superscriptğ‘¥â€²ğ‘¥ğ›¾x^{\prime}=x\gammaitalic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_x italic_Î³.

For such an xğ‘¥xitalic_x, as the elements of Vâ¢aâ¢râ¢(si)ğ‘‰ğ‘ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘–Var(s_{i})italic_V italic_a italic_r ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) only occur in those tksubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘˜t_{k}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT such that kâˆˆDâ¢oâ¢mâ¢(Ï„+â¢(q))ğ‘˜ğ·ğ‘œğ‘šsuperscriptğœğ‘k\in Dom(\tau^{+}(q))italic_k âˆˆ italic_D italic_o italic_m ( italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) ) (because Ï„+superscriptğœ\tau^{+}italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is DN for cğ‘citalic_c) and as xâˆˆVâ¢aâ¢râ¢(tj)ğ‘¥ğ‘‰ğ‘ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘—x\in Var(t_{j})italic_x âˆˆ italic_V italic_a italic_r ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) with jâˆ‰Dâ¢oâ¢mâ¢(Ï„+â¢(q))ğ‘—ğ·ğ‘œğ‘šsuperscriptğœğ‘j\not\in Dom(\tau^{+}(q))italic_j âˆ‰ italic_D italic_o italic_m ( italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) ), we have xâˆ‰Vâ¢aâ¢râ¢(si)ğ‘¥ğ‘‰ğ‘ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘–x\not\in Var(s_{i})italic_x âˆ‰ italic_V italic_a italic_r ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). So, as Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³ is a 1-1 and onto mapping from its domain to itself, we have xâ¢Î³âˆ‰Vâ¢aâ¢râ¢(siâ¢Î³)ğ‘¥ğ›¾ğ‘‰ğ‘ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘–ğ›¾x\gamma\not\in Var(s_{i}\gamma)italic_x italic_Î³ âˆ‰ italic_V italic_a italic_r ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î³ ) (see footnoteÂ 1), i.e. xâ€²â‰ Vâ¢aâ¢râ¢(siâ€²)superscriptğ‘¥â€²ğ‘‰ğ‘ğ‘Ÿsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘ â€²ğ‘–x^{\prime}\neq Var(s^{\prime}_{i})italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰  italic_V italic_a italic_r ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). Contradiction!

Therefore, for each qâ¢(t1â€²,â€¦,tmâ€²)âˆˆğâ€²ğ‘subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¡â€²1â€¦subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¡â€²ğ‘šsuperscriptğâ€²q(t^{\prime}_{1},\dots,t^{\prime}_{m})\in\textup{\bf B}^{\prime}italic_q ( italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) âˆˆ B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and jâˆ‰Dâ¢oâ¢mâ¢(Ï„+â¢(q))ğ‘—ğ·ğ‘œğ‘šsuperscriptğœğ‘j\not\in Dom(\tau^{+}(q))italic_j âˆ‰ italic_D italic_o italic_m ( italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ) ), we have Vâ¢aâ¢râ¢(siâ€²)âˆ©Vâ¢aâ¢râ¢(tjâ€²)=âˆ…ğ‘‰ğ‘ğ‘Ÿsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘ â€²ğ‘–ğ‘‰ğ‘ğ‘Ÿsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘¡â€²ğ‘—Var(s^{\prime}_{i})\cap Var(t^{\prime}_{j})=\varnothingitalic_V italic_a italic_r ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) âˆ© italic_V italic_a italic_r ( italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = âˆ….

(DN4)

Let qâ¢(t1â€²,â€¦,tmâ€²)âˆˆğâ€²ğ‘subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¡â€²1â€¦subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¡â€²ğ‘šsuperscriptğâ€²q(t^{\prime}_{1},\dots,t^{\prime}_{m})\in\textup{\bf B}^{\prime}italic_q ( italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) âˆˆ B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and âŸ¨jâ†¦ujâŸ©âˆˆÏ„+â¢(q)delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©maps-toğ‘—subscriptğ‘¢ğ‘—superscriptğœğ‘\langle j\mapsto u_{j}\rangle\in\tau^{+}(q)âŸ¨ italic_j â†¦ italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ© âˆˆ italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_q ). As tjsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘—t_{j}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is an instance of ujsubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘—u_{j}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (because Ï„+superscriptğœ\tau^{+}italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is DN for cğ‘citalic_c) and as tjâ€²subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¡â€²ğ‘—t^{\prime}_{j}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a variant of tjsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘—t_{j}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, tjâ€²subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¡â€²ğ‘—t^{\prime}_{j}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is an instance of ujsubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘—u_{j}italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Finally, we have established that Ï„+superscriptğœ\tau^{+}italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is DN for câ€²superscriptğ‘â€²c^{\prime}italic_c start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. âˆ

9 Appendix 2: DN Sets of Positions with Associated Terms Generate DN Filters

In this section, we give a proof of TheoremÂ 4.2.

9.1 Context

All the results of this section are parametric to the following context:

  • â€¢

    Ï„+superscriptğœ\tau^{+}italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT denotes a set of positions with associated terms that is DN for a program Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P,

  • â€¢

    Qâ¢âŸ¹cÎ¸Q1ğ‘„subscriptsuperscriptâŸ¹ğœƒğ‘subscriptğ‘„1Q\mathop{\Longrightarrow}\limits^{\theta}_{c}Q_{1}italic_Q âŸ¹ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is an SLD-derivation step where

      câˆˆPğ‘ğ‘ƒc\in Pitalic_c âˆˆ italic_P,

  • â€¢

    Qâ€²:=ğ€â€²,pâ¢(t1â€²,â€¦,tnâ€²),ğ‚â€²assignsuperscriptğ‘„â€²superscriptğ€â€²ğ‘subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¡â€²1â€¦subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¡â€²ğ‘›superscriptğ‚â€²Q^{\prime}:=\textup{\bf A}^{\prime},p(t^{\prime}_{1},\dots,t^{\prime}_{n}),\textup{\bf C}^{\prime}italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT := A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_p ( italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is Î”â¢[Ï„+]Î”delimited-[]superscriptğœ\Delta[\tau^{+}]roman_Î” [ italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ]-more general than Qğ‘„Qitalic_Q i.e., by PropositionÂ 1, there exists a substitution Î·ğœ‚\etaitalic_Î· such that Vâ¢aâ¢râ¢(Î·)âŠ†Vâ¢aâ¢râ¢(Q,Qâ€²)ğ‘‰ğ‘ğ‘Ÿğœ‚ğ‘‰ğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘„superscriptğ‘„â€²Var(\eta)\subseteq Var(Q,Q^{\prime})italic_V italic_a italic_r ( italic_Î· ) âŠ† italic_V italic_a italic_r ( italic_Q , italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) and Qâ€²superscriptğ‘„â€²Q^{\prime}italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is Î”â¢[Ï„+]Î”delimited-[]superscriptğœ\Delta[\tau^{+}]roman_Î” [ italic_Ï„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ]-more general than Qğ‘„Qitalic_Q for Î·ğœ‚\etaitalic_Î·.
